DT Article
TI New taxa of quill mites (Acari: Cheyletoidea: Syringophilidae).
AU Skoracki, Maciej (skoracki@amu.edu.pl) 
   OConnor, Barry
SO Zootaxa
VL 2341
PS 1-32
PD 22 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02341p032.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB Four new genera and eight new species are described: Apodisyringophilus
   collocalius gen. nov., sp. nov. from Collocalia esculenta (Linnaeus)
   (Apodiformes: Apodidae) from the Philippines, Bochkovia phalaropi gen.
   nov., sp. nov. from Phalaropus fulicarius (Linnaeus) (Charadriiformes:
   Scolopacidae) from the USA, Ciconichenophilus phoeniconaias gen. nov.,
   sp. nov. and Stibarokris phoeniconaias sp. nov. from Phoeniconaias minor
   (Geoffroy Saint- Hilaire) (Phoenicopteriformes: Phoenicopteridae) from
   Botswana, Picisyringophilus kratos gen. nov., sp. nov. from Picoides
   pubescens (Linnaeus) (Piciformes: Picidae) from the USA, Charadriiphilus
   re sp. nov. and Picobia pteroclesi sp. nov. from Pterocles senegallus
   (Linnaeus) (Pteroclidiformes: Pteroclididae) from Egypt, and
   Neoaulonastus chrysocolaptes sp. nov. from Chrysocolaptes lucidus
   (Scopoli) (Piciformes: Picidae) from the Philippines. The new genera
   differ from the closely related genera by the following characters:
   Apodisyringophilus gen. nov. differs from Syringophiloidus Kethley by
   the absence of leg setae lGIV, the presence of the short hysteronotal
   setae and by apodemes I fused to apodemes II; Bochkovia gen. nov.
   differs from Procellariisyringophilus Schmidt et Skoracki by the
   presence of the dentate cheliceral stylets and two pairs of pseudanal
   setae, the absence of setae vsI and by the presence of the strongly
   curved claws on tarsi I-IV; Ciconichenophilus gen. nov. differs from
   Chenophila Kethley by the stylophore rounded posteriorly, the long
   hysteronotal setae, apodemes I not fused to apodemes II and by the
   absence of leg setae vsII; Picisyringophilus gen. nov. differs from
   Mironovia Chirov et Kravtsova by coxal fields I and II subequal in sizes
   and by setae se situated distinctly anterior to setae c1. Data on
   distribution of all known syringophilid genera on host families and
   orders are provided.

   Poland.

DT Article
TI A new species of Ptychochromis from northeastern Madagascar (Teleostei:
   Cichlidae), with an updated phylogeny and revised diagnosis for the
   genus.
AU Sparks, John S. (jsparks@amnh.org) 
   Stiassny, Melanie L.J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2341
PS 33-51
PD 22 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02341p051.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species belonging to the endemic Malagasy cichlid genus
   Ptychochromis is described. Ptychochromis ernestmagnusi is known only
   from the middle to lower reaches of the Mananara River in northeastern
   Madagascar. Based on a unique configuration of the palatine, the new
   species is placed among the species of Ptychochromis considered to have
   an eastern-type palatine morphology by Stiassny and Sparks (2006). The
   new species is further distinguished from members of the "western clade"
   of Ptychochromis by anterior displacement of the first supraneural such
   that it overlies the dorsoposterior margin of the supraoccipital. Among
   species of Ptychochromis with eastern-type palatine morphology, P.
   ernestmagnusi shares with P. makira the possession of supraneurals with
   a characteristically flattened dorsal profile. Although P. makira and P.
   ernestmagnusi both possess paired lateral barring pigmentation patterns,
   the lateral flank bars in P. makira are distinctively V-shaped, whereas
   in P. ernestmagnusi they are oriented vertically. Ptychochromis
   ernestmagnusi is further distinguished from P. makira by prominent
   iridescent spangling on the flank and dorsal fin near its base, dusky
   grayish-green base coloration (vs. whitish), four laterosensory foramina
   on the lachrymal (vs. three), and a series of seven (vs. six)
   infraorbital bones. In addition, an updated phylogeny and diagnosis for
   Ptychochromis is presented, including anatomical data for the new
   species and novel anatomical data for the genus.
C1 Sparks, John S.; Department of Ichthyology, Division of Vertebrate
   Zoology, American Museum of Natural History, New York, NY 10024, USA,
   USA.
EM jsparks@amnh.org
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; General morphology;
   Evolution; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Ptychochromis [General morphology /  / ] [Phylogeny / Cladistics / ]. 
   Ptychochromis ernestmagnusi [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae
OR Ptychochromis - Steindachner 1880 (Cichlidae): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   34]. 
   Ptychochromis ernestmagnusi (Cichlidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 34]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603024158

AN ZOOR14603024159
DT Article
TI Earthworm fauna of eastern Taiwan, with descriptions of two new species
   (Oligochaeta: Megascolecidae).
AU Wang, Yu-Hsi (htshih@dragon.nchu.edu.tw) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2341
PS 52-68
PD 22 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02341p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The earthworm fauna of eastern Taiwan was studied, and two new species,
   viz. Amynthas shinjiroi sp. nov. and Pithemera tao sp. nov. are
   described. Other species from our collection included Dichogaster
   (Diplothecodrilus) saliens (Beddard, 1893), Amynthas aspergillum
   (Perrier, 1872), A. gracilis (Kinberg, 1867), A. aff. hupeiensis
   (Michaelsen, 1891), A. robustus (Perrier, 1872), A. aff. morrisi
   (Beddard, 1892), Pithemera bicincta (Perrier, 1875), P. lanyuensis Shen
   & Tsai, 2002, and Pontoscolex corethrurus (Muller, 1856). Pithemera
   lanyuensis was first collected on Lanyu (Orchid Island), but its
   distribution is now extended to the main island of Taiwan. The finding
   of the exotic Pontoscolex corethrurus in eastern Taiwan shows it has
   probably invaded the entire island of Taiwan, and its impacts upon the
   ecology and agriculture need to be studied in the future.
C1 Wang, Yu-Hsi; Department of Life Science, National Chung Hsing
   University, 250 Kuo-Kuang Road, Taichung 402, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM htshih@dragon.nchu.edu.tw
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Amynthas shinjiroi; Pithemera tao [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
   Megascolecidae [Taiwan / East / Faunal list; systematics]. 
   Pithemera lanyuensis [Taiwan / Taitung County, Basiandong / New record].

DT Article
TI Review of the genus Petropedetes Reichenow, 1874 in Central Africa with
   the description of three new species (Amphibia: Anura: Petropedetidae).
AU Barej, Michael F. (michael@barej.de) 
   Roedel, Mark-Oliver
   Gonwouo, Legrand Nono
   Pauwels, Olivier S.G.
   Boehme, Wolfgang
   Schmitz, Andreas
SO Zootaxa
VL 2340
PS 1-49
PD 21 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02340p049.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We review and summarize the present knowledge on Central African
   Petropedetes, discuss their taxonomy and describe three new species. We
   synonymise one name: P. newtonii is a junior synonym of P. johnstoni.
   Frogs from the African mainland, namely Cameroon and eastern Nigeria,
   assigned to "P. newtonii" in more recent literature, were misidentified.
   They are herein described anew as Petropedetes vulpiae sp. nov. Two
   further new taxa are morphologically similar to other described species.
   Petropedetes euskircheni sp. nov. is morphologically close to P. parkeri
   but differs foremost in the smaller size of the femoral glands in adult
   males. P. juliawurstnerae sp. nov. is morphologically similar to P.
   perreti and P. cameronensis. It can be distinguished from P. perreti by
   its less developed webbing and from P. cameronensis by the size of its
   tympanum and the occurrence of a tympanic papilla in males. A key to
   adult males of the currently known Central African Petropedetes species
   is given and an outlook on potential further new taxa is provided.
C1 Barej, Michael F.; Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum, Alexander Koenig,
   Adenauerallee 160, 53113 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM michael@barej.de
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326

   zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   Tympanoceros newtonii du Bocage 1895, p. 12]. 
   Petropedetes juliawurstnerae (Ranidae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 35].

DT Article
TI Cottus immaculatus, a new species of sculpin (Cottidae) from the Ozark
   Highlands of Arkansas and Missouri, USA.
AU Kinziger, Andrew P. (Andrew.Kinziger@Humboldt.edu) 
   Wood, Robert M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2340
PS 50-64
PD 21 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02340p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Cottus immaculatus, new species, is described from the Current, Eleven
   Point, Spring and White river systems of the White River drainage, in
   the Ozark Highlands of Arkansas and Missouri, USA. Cottus immaculatus is
   a member of the Uranidea clade and distinguishable from all members of
   the genus Cottus using genetic and morphological characters. Cottus
   immaculatus possesses a previously unreported but possibly widespread
   character in the genus Cottus, enlargement of the tips of the dorsal-fin
   spines of males. The description of Cottus immaculatus brings the total
   number of species recognized within the genus Cottus to 68.
C1 Kinziger, Andrew P.; Department of Fisheries Biology, Humboldt State
   University, One Harpst Street, Arcata, CA 95521, USA, USA.

   America; USA

AN ZOOR14606040959
DT Article
TI Hemiscyllium michaeli, a new species of bamboo shark (Hemiscyllidae)
   from Papua New Guinea.
AU Allen, Gerald R. (tropical_reef@bigpond.com) 
   Dudgeon, Christine L.
SO Aqua (Miradolo Terme)
VL 16
IS 1
PS 19-30
PD 20 January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Hemiscyllium michaeli new species is described from six specimens,
   257-695 mm TL, collected at eastern Papua New Guinea. The species was
   previously confused with H. freycineti, which is restricted to Papua
   Barat Province (western New Guinea), Indonesia. The two species differ
   primarily in colour pattern, which provides the best means of separating
   the various members of the genus. Both species have a profuse covering
   of brown spots with a large black or brown ocellated marking on the
   middle of the side, just behind the head. The spots of H. michaeli n.
   sp. are generally denser, larger, and distinctly polygonal, remarkably
   similar to the spots of a leopard. In contrast those of H. freycineti
   are round to transversely elongate and are darkened at regular intervals
   to form 8-9 bars or saddle-like markings (including those on the tail).
   The difference in spot pattern between the two species is particularly
   evident in the head region. In addition, H. michaeli n. sp. possesses a
   vivid ocellate black spot behind the head, whereas the black spot of H.
   freycineti is generally not well defined. Comparison of the
   mitochondrial ND4 gene also supports the species-level separation of
   these species.
C1 Allen, Gerald R.; Department of Aquatic Vertebrates, Western Australian
   Museum, Locked Bag 49, Welshpool DC, Perth, Western Australia 6000,
   Australia.
EM tropical_reef@bigpond.com
RI Dudgeon, Christine/A-1633-2017
OI Dudgeon, Christine/0000-0001-5059-7886
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0945-9871
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Biometrics; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Hemiscyllium [Size / Species morphometric measurements / ] [South
   Pacific / New Guinea / distribution]. 
   Hemiscyllium michaeli [South Pacific / Papua New Guinea / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes, Elasmobranchii,
   Orectolobiformes, Hemiscylliidae
OR Hemiscyllium - Muller & Henle 1838 (Hemiscylliidae): [Key to species, P.
   29]. 
   Hemiscyllium michaeli (Hemiscylliidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea
   (marine), P. 22]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14606040959

TI A new species of Leptolalax (Anura: Megophryidae) from the sacred groves
   of Mawphlang, Meghalaya, north-eastern Indi.
AU Das, Indraneil (idas@ibec.unimas.my) 
   Lyngdoh Tron, Ronald K.
   Rangad, Duwaki
   Hooroo, Rupa N.K.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2339
PS 44-56
PD 20 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02339p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of megophryid frog of the genus Leptolalax is described
   from the sacred groves of Mawphlang, East Khasi Hills, north-eastern
   India. L. khasiorum new species, is compared with congeners from India
   and other parts of south-east Asia. The new species is diagnosable in
   showing the following combination of characters: SVL 24.5[long dash]27.3
   (mean 25.63 [plus or minus] 0.61 SE) mm in a sample of four adult males;
   31.2[long dash]33.4 (mean 32.50 [plus or minus] 0.67 SE) mm in a sample
   of three females; dorsum with fine scattered tubercles; eyelids with
   tubercles; tympanum and supratympanic fold distinct; macroglands,
   including preaxillary, pectorals and ventrolateral glands present;
   Finger I > II; toe tips not dilated, bearing dermal fringes; dorsum with
   dark blotches; flanks with large dark blotches; dark tympanic mask
   present; venter lacking dark blotches; labial bars present and limbs
   with dark cross-bars.
C1 Das, Indraneil; Institute of Biodiversity and Environmental
   Conservation, Universiti Malaysia Sarawak, 94300, Kota Samarahan,
   Sarawak, Malaysia, Malaysia.

DT Article
TI A new species of the Rhinella margaritifera group (Anura: Bufonidae)
   from Brazilian Pantanal.
AU Avila, Robson W. (robsonavila@gmail.com) 
   Pansonato, Andre
   Struessmann, Christine
SO Zootaxa
VL 2339
PS 57-68
PD 20 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02339p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe adult morphology, advertisement call and some natural
   history traits of a new species of toad from the Pantanal, western
   Brazil. Rhinella paraguayensis sp. nov. belongs to the Rhinella
   margaritifera group, and is characterized by medium size, snout rounded
   in dorsal view, with a vertical apical ridge, supraorbital crests weakly
   developed, parietal crest not well developed, postorbital crest
   prominent, presence of a dorsolateral line of tubercles, tympanum
   evident, bony protrusions at angle of jaws, absence of vertebral
   apophyses and of projections on upper eyelids, and parotoid glands
   small. The new species is distinguished from other species of the group
   by geographic distribution and by the use of floating mats of vegetation
   as reproductive site.
C1 Avila, Robson W.; Departamento de Parasitologia, Instituto de
   Biociencias, Universidade Estadual Paulista, Distrito de Rubiao Jr.
   s/no, CEP 18618-000, Botucatu, SP, Brazil, Brazil.

TI Review of Afrotropical Thienemanniella Kieffer (Diptera: Chironomidae:
   Orthocladiinae).
AU Fu, Yue (ole.sather@zmb.uib.no) 
   Hestenes, Tor Christian
   Saether, Ole
SO Zootaxa
VL 2338
PS 1-22
PD 19 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02338p022.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species from Ghana, Thienemanniella cavata is described and
   illustrated as adult male. T. antennata Freeman, 1953, T. trivittata
   Goetghebuer, 1935 and T. lineola Freeman, 1953 are redescribed.
   Additional measurements and comments are given for T. fuga Lehmann,
   1979. Additional records of T. antennata from Ghana and T. fuga from
   South Africa and Tanzania are given. T. afra Lehmann, 1981 is
   tentatively transferred to the genus Corynoneurella Brundin. Male and
   female genital structures are discussed. A large bursa below
   gonapophysis VIII and the vagina is considered to be an egg-laying
   chamber. Keys to the known males and females of Afrotropical species of
   the genus Thienemanniella are given.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Eupholus Boisduval (Coleoptera, Curculionidae,
   Entiminae), with observations on coloured cuticular exudates in weevils.
AU Riedel, Alexander (riedel@smnk.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2338
PS 23-34
PD 19 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02338p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Eupholus Boisduval from Papua New Guinea are
   described as new: Eupholus mimicus sp. n. and E. sedlaceki sp. n.. A key
   to the Eupholus species with yellow colour patterns is provided. E.
   sedlaceki is closely related to E. euphrosyne Porion but differs in
   coloration. Male and female terminalia of E. euphrosyne are illustrated
   for comparison. E. mimicus is superficially very similar to E.
   euphrosyne, but its yellow colour pattern is composed of scales whereas
   in the latter it is formed by loose particles. These two species belong
   to different species groups, and the conspicuous colour patterns have
   evidently evolved convergently. The occurrence and function of
   extracuticular pigments among species of Eupholini is discussed.
C1 Riedel, Alexander; Staatliches Museum fuer Naturkunde, Erbprinzenstr.
   13, D-76133 Karlsruhe, Germany, Germany.

   morphology; Appendages; Colour and luminescence; Colour; Integument;
   Reproduction; Reproductive system; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia

DT Article
TI An endemic predaceous water beetle from the Murchison River in Western
   Australia - Antiporus kalbarriensis sp.n. (Coleoptera: Dytiscidae,
   Hydroporinae, Hydroporini).
AU Hendrich, Lars (hendrich1@aol.com) 
   Watts, Chris H.S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2338
PS 35-42
PD 19 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02338p042.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Antiporus kalbarriensis sp.n. is described from the Murchison bioregion
   in Western Australia. The species appears to be restricted to backwater
   pools and oxbows along the Murchison River. Morphologically it is near
   Antiporus bakewellii (Clark, 1862) (Queensland, New South Wales), A.
   jenniferae Watts, 1997 (Northern Territory, N Queensland, NW Australia)
   and A. simplex Watts, 1978 (Queensland) but differs by the form of the
   median lobe, size and male proclaw. The habitat and its water beetle
   coenosis are described in detail. Additional distributional records for
   A. bakewellii and A. jenniferae are given. Altogether 15 species of
   Antiporus are now reported from Australia. The new species underline the
   importance of south-western Australia as a hotspot of diversity for
   Dytiscidae of the tribe Hydroporini Aube, 1836.
C1 Hendrich, Lars; Zoologische Staatssammlung, Muenchhausenstrasse 21,
   D-81247 Berlin, Germany, Germany.
EM hendrich1@aol.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326

   zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia

   Zealand /  / ].

   River / New record] [Queensland / Kenilworth, Obi Obi Creek / ]. 
   Antiporus jenniferae [Northern Territory / Kakadu Highway Bowerbird
   Creek / New record]. 
   Antiporus kalbarriensis [Western Australia /  / New species].

DT Article
TI The enigma of the genus Stenaphorura Absolon, 1900 (Collembola,
   Tullbergiinae).
AU Rusek, Josef (rusek@upb.cas.cz) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2338
PS 43-53
PD 19 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02338p053.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Stenaphorura japygiformis Absolon, 1900 was redescribed based on the
   holotype and on virtually topotypic material from the Moravian Karst,
   Czech Republic. Lectotype of Stenaphorura lubbocki Bagnall, 1935 was
   redescribed and used for comparison with S. japygiformis. The
   postantennal organ, composed of 50[long dash]56 simple vesicles, is 3.8
   times the length of the frontal pseudocellus in S. japygiformis,
   compared to 75 vesicles and 6.3 times in the related S. lubbocki.
   Figures and measurements of some structures are given for the first
   time. As a consequence of my studies Stenaphorurella Lucianez & Simon,
   1992 is sunk into synonymy of Stenaphorura Absolon, 1900. All species
   transferred into Stenaphorurella by Lucianez & Simon (1992) and by
   Khanislamova et al. (1997) are reintroduced into Stenaphorura Absolon,
   1900.
C1 Rusek, Josef; Institute of Soil Biology BC AS, v.v.i., Na Sadkach, 370
   05 Ceske Budijovice, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM rusek@upb.cas.cz
RI Rusek, Josef/G-1481-2014
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Diagnosis; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Collembola
OR Stenaphorura - Absolon 1900 (Collembola): [Systematics, P. 44;
   Redescription, Holotype female & virtually topotypic material, p. 45;
   Syn nov, Stenaphorurella Lucianez & Simon 1992, p. 52]. 
   Stenaphorura absoloni - Bagnall 1936 (Collembola): [Combination
   revalidated, Transferred back from Stenaphorurella, p. 52].

AB Five new species of Paduniella (Trichoptera: Psychomyiidae) are
   described: P. flinti, P. nandra, P. ambra, P. madagassa, and P. sona,
   representing the first records of the genus from Madagascar and more
   than doubling the number of Paduniella species known from the
   Afrotropical Region.

TI Notes on the Asian genus Cricula Walker, 1855, with description of new
   species (Lepidoptera, Saturniidae).
AU Naumann, Stefan (sn@saturniidae.com) 
   Loeffler, Swen
SO Neue Entomologische Nachrichten
SU Supplement 2
PS 1-24
PD Jan 18 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A survey about new records and species of the genus Cricula WALKER, 1855
   is presented. 15 species are described as new: C. aungsansuukyiae spec.
   nov. from Myanmar and India; C. falcata spec. nov., C. frederkingi spec.
   nov., C. schintlmeisteri spec. nov., C. griseorubrescens spec. nov., C.
   fansipanensis spec. nov., C. hoffmanni spec. nov., C. sponai spec. nov.,
   C. hoabinhnguyeni spec. nov., all from Vietnam; C. pseudandrei spec.
   nov. and C. variabilis spec. nov. from PR China; C. maxalovensis spec.
   nov., C. separata spec. nov. and C. baliensis spec. nov. from Indonesia,
   and C. magnifenestrata spec. nov. from Malaysia and Indonesia. Holotypes
   and allotypes where known. [male] genitalia structures and paratype
   specimens plus related taxa are figured. All holotypes from the authors'
   collections will be given to the entomological collections of the
   "Zoologisches Museum der Humboldt-Universitat zu Berlin" (ZMHU).

DT Article
TI Notes on taxa of the genus Antheraea Hubner, 1819 from Indonesia, with
   the description of five new species (Lepidoptera, Saturniidae).
AU Naumann, Stefan (sn@saturniidae.com) 
SO Neue Entomologische Nachrichten
SU Supplement 2
PS 25-35
PD Jan 18 2010
PY 2010
NT With contribution from: Loeffler, S.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new species of the genus Antheraea HUBNER 1819 ("1816") in the
   subgenus ANTHERAEA, are described from Indonesia: A. sumbaensis spec.
   nov. from Sumba Island; A. kalabahiensis spec. nov. from Alor and Pantar
   Islands: A. cadioui spec. nov. from Siberut, Pagai Utara and Tanahmasa
   Islands, all in the Mentawai Archipelago A. rolfei spec. nov. from
   Taliabu Mangole, Sula Islands; and A. loeffleri spec. nov. from Obi
   Island, Moluccas. Male holotypes from the senior authors's collection
   will be deposited in the collection of Zoologisches Museum der
   Humboldt-Universitat zu Berlin, Germany. All holotype specimens, the
   according allotypes (where known) plus some other specimens dealt with
   and their [male] genitalia structures are figured for comparision.
   Antheraea tenggarensis BRECHLIN, 2000 syn. nov.. is found to be a junior
   synonym of the widespread A. jana (STOLL, 1782).

PT J
AN ZOOR14603023991
DT Article
TI A new species of Allobates (Anura: Aromobatidae) from Paleovarzea Forest
   in Amazonas, Brazil.
AU Lima, Albertina P. (lima@inpa.gov.br) 
   Caldwell, Janalee P.
   Biavati, Graziela
   Montanarin, Anelise
SO Zootaxa
VL 2337
PS 1-17
PD 18 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/z02337p017f.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Numerous species of aromobatid frogs in the genus Allobates from the
   Amazonian region of Brazil have been described in recent years. Herein,
   we describe a new Allobates from the state of Amazonas. This species is
   allopatric with three other species of Allobates, two of which we have
   described previously. The new species inhabits streams in small remnants
   of paleovarzea forest along margins of a small river, the Parana do
   Castanho. Paleovarzeas are ancient floodplains of the Amazon River and
   its tributaries. Paleovarzea forests are transitional between terra
   firme forests, which are never flooded, and varzeas, which are
   seasonally flooded. Males and females of the new species are similar in
   size; males average 20.1 mm, females 19.8. Tadpoles have a distinct dark
   brown bar extending from the snout through the eye to midbody. The call
   of this species consists of quickly repeated groups of single notes and
   is unique compared to known species of Allobates. Courtship includes
   cephalic amplexus. Eggs are deposited on the forest floor in cup-shaped
   leaves in the litter. Unlike other species of Allobates, egg capsules in
   this species are opaque instead of clear.
C1 Lima, Albertina P.; Coordenacao de Pesquisas em Ecologia, Instituto
   Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazonia, Av. Andre Araujo 2936, 69011-970,
   Manaus, Amazonas, Brazil, Brazil.
EM lima@inpa.gov.br
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Allobates paleovarzensis [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Dendrobatidae
OR Allobates paleovarzensis (Dendrobatidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 3]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023991
DA 2020-09-17
ER

TI New taxa in the Eriophyidae (Acari, Prostigmata) from forest trees in
   southern Brazil.
AU Flechtmann, Carlos H.W. (chwflech@esalq.usp.br) 
   de Queiroz, Dalva L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2337

AB Two new genera and five new species of Eriophyidae from forest trees in
   southern Brazil are described, namely: Juxtacolopodacus n. gen.,
   Juxtacolopodacus phalakros n. sp. from Mollinedia clavigera Tul.
   (Monimiaceae); Procalacarus perporosus n. sp., from Randia armata (Sw.)
   (Rubiaceae); Scolotosus Flechtmann & Keifer, n.gen., Scolotosus
   centrolobii Flechtmann & Keifer, n. sp., from Centrolobium robustum
   Mart. (Leguminosae); Scolotosus hartfordi n. sp., from Centrolobium
   tomentosum Guill. (Leguminosae), and Metaculus tanythrix n. sp., from
   Dicksonia sellowiana Hook. (Dicksoniaceae).

AN ZOOR14603023994
DT Article
TI Uca jocelynae sp. nov., a new species of fiddler crab (Crustacea:
   Brachyura: Ocypodidae) from the western Pacific.
AU Shih, Hsi-Te (htshih@dragon.nchu.edu.tw) 
   Naruse, Tohru
   Ng, Peter K.L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2337
PS 47-62
PD 18 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/z02337p062f.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of fiddler crab, Uca jocelynae sp. nov., belonging to the
   U. vocans complex, is described from the islands in Western Pacific on
   the basis of morphological and molecular data. The new species was
   previously identified with U. neocultrimana (Bott, 1973) (= U. vocans
   pacificensis Crane, 1975). The two species can be readily distinguished
   by characters of the male major chelae, carapace features, and the form
   of the vulvae. The molecular data of parts of the mitochondrial 16S rRNA
   and cytochrome oxidase I (COI) genes support that both are sister taxa
   but nevertheless distinct enough to be regarded as separate species. Uca
   jocelynae is widely distributed from the islands in the Western Pacific,
   while U. neocultrimana occurs in Fiji and eastwards.
C1 Shih, Hsi-Te; Department of Life Science, National Chung Hsing
   University, 250, Kuo Kuang Road, Taichung 402, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM htshih@dragon.nchu.edu.tw
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Uca jocelynae [North Pacific / Indonesia / New species] [ / Japan / ] [
   / Philippines / ] [ / Taiwan / ] [South Pacific / Papua New Guinea / ] [
   / Vanuatu / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Uca jocelynae (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Taiwan (marine), P. 51]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023994

DT Article
TI Mud shrimp associated with burrows from the Oligocene Ashiya Group,
   northern Kyushu, Japan, with description of a new species of Upogebia
   (Decapoda: Gebiidea).
AU Ando, Yusuke (tyyu-destiny53@hotmail.co.jp) 
   Karasawa, Hiroaki
SO Zootaxa
VL 2337
PS 63-68
PD 18 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/z02337p068f.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Upogebia hibiki sp. nov. (Gebiidea: Upogebiidae) is described from the
   Oligocene of northern Kyushu, Japan. The new species closely resembles
   U. mizunamiensis Karasawa 1989, but differs in having an arched ridge on
   the dorso-distal mesial surface of the palm of pereiopod 1.
   Additionally, the new species has a triangular rostrum and a narrow
   gastric region. The specimens are associated with fossil burrows
   assigned to the ichnogenus Psilonichnus Fursich, 1981. Therefore,
   Psilonichnus described herein is thought to be formed by U. hibiki sp.
   nov.
C1 Ando, Yusuke; Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Nagoya
   University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-8601, Japan, Japan.
EM tyyu-destiny53@hotmail.co.jp
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1175-5326

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene

   (Crustacea); tracemaker identity; burrow description] [Japan / Kyushu /
   fossil burrows attributed to Upogebia hibiki (Crustacea)] [Oligocene / 
   / ]. 
   Upogebia [Japan /  / new record] [Oligocene /  / ]. 
   Upogebia hibiki [Fossil burrows /  / Psilonichnus; tracemaker identity;

   Upogebia (Anomura): [Fossil; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14607044420
DT Article
TI Messinian Lago-Mare deposits near the Strait of Gibraltar (Malaga Basin,
   S Spain).
AU Guerra-Merchan, A. (antguerra@uma.es) 
   Serrano, F.
   Garces, M.
   Gofas, S.
   Esu, D.
   Gliozzi, E.
   Grossi, F.
SO Palaeogeography Palaeoclimatology Palaeoecology
VL 285
IS 3-4
PS 264-276
PD January 15 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 4
U2 16
AB A new stratigraphic unit (named LM unit) located at the base of the
   Pliocene marine succession in the eastern sector of the Malaga Basin has
   been distinguished. This unit is composed of two fining-upward sequences
   bounded by a discontinuity related to synsedimentary tectonic activity.
   Both sequences are made up of basal alluvial deposits overlain by
   subaquatic deposits. The lower sequence contains rich mollusc faunas
   characterized by bivalves Lymnocardiinae and Dreissenidae of Paratethyan
   origin, and non-marine gastropods, typical of oligo-low mesohaline
   shallow waters, and low diversified ostracod faunas of Paratethyan
   origin (Loxocorniculina djafarovi, Tyrrhenocythere pontica,
   Euxinocythere (Maeotocythere) praebaquana and Amnicythere propinqua)
   typical of low mesohaline waters. Alternances of monospecific ostracod
   assemblages made of Cyprideis agrigentina or oligotypic assemblages made
   of C agrigentina and Loxoconcha spp. and richer assemblages made of L
   djafarovi accompanied by several Ammicythere spp. and Camptocypria sp. 1
   characterize the upper sequence, pointing to more unstable environment
   affected by salinity and depth changes. Some samples collected from this
   upper sequence yielded rare, planktonic and benthic foraminifera, which
   could suggest the sporadic establishment of quasi-normal marine
   conditions in the westernmost Mediterranean during the deposition of
   this sequence. The palaeontological data and the palaeomagnetic results
   obtained in both the LM unit and the overlying Pliocene marine sediments
   restrict the age of the former to the post-evaporitic late Messinian.
   The age and the environmental conditions correlate these deposits with
   the Lago-Mare event occurring throughout the Mediterranean before the
   quick and widespread marine flooding of the Mediterranean at the
   beginning of the Pliocene. (C) 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Guerra-Merchan, A.; Univ Malaga, Fac Ciencias, Malaga, Spain, Spain.
EM antguerra@uma.es
RI garces, miguel/D-4386-2014; Serrano, Francisco/L-7122-2014;
   Guerra-Merchan, Antonio/L-5785-2014; Esu, Daniela/D-3024-2009
OI garces, miguel/0000-0001-7666-6392; Serrano,
   Francisco/0000-0003-4750-5973; Guerra-Merchan,
   Antonio/0000-0002-6753-8011; Gliozzi, Elsa/0000-0001-5608-1995; Gofas,
   Serge Salvator/0000-0002-3141-3700
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0031-0182

   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene

   Malaga Basin / stratigraphical distribution] [Miocene / Messinian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Molluscs; Protozoans

   Foraminiferida (Granuloreticulosea): [Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14607044426
DT Article
TI Comment on 'A high latitude vertebrate fossil assemblage from the Late
   Cretaceous of west-central Alberta, Canada: evidence for dinosaur
   nesting and vertebrate latitudinal gradient' By F. Fanti and T.
   Miyashita (Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology 275 (2009)
   37-53).
AU Fox, Richard C. (richard.fox@ualberta.ca) 
   Scott, Craig S.
SO Palaeogeography Palaeoclimatology Palaeoecology
VL 285
IS 3-4
PS 354-356
PD January 15 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A recent paper by Fanti and Miyashita (2009. A high latitude vertebrate
   fossil assemblage from the Late Cretaceous of west-central Alberta,
   Canada: Evidence for dinosaur nesting and vertebrate latitudinal
   gradient Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology 275, 37-53)
   reports on a new assemblage of terrestrial vertebrate fossils from the
   Campanian (Late Cretaceous) of northern Alberta. In addition to the
   several dinosaur and microvertebrate specimens reported by Fanti and
   Miyashita (2009), the new assemblage also contains two mammalian teeth,
   identified by the authors as pertaining to "Cimolodon sp." and
   "Didelphodon sp." The taxonomic identifications of these teeth are
   either highly questionable or simply incorrect, and the accompanying
   descriptions are replete with errors; as a result of these lapses, at
   least part of the biogeographic conclusions drawn by the authors about
   the Kleskun Hills Park area is also rendered incorrect. While the
   discovery of a Late Cretaceous high-latitude vertebrate fauna in Alberta
   is unquestionably important, the significance of the Kleskun Hills
   mammalian taxa, both taxonomically and biogeographically, should be
   reconsidered. (C) 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Fox, Richard C.; Univ Alberta, Dept Biol Sci, Edmonton, AB, Canada,
   Canada.
EM richard.fox@ualberta.ca
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0031-0182
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Dentition; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; Canada; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Cimolodon; Didelphodon [Teeth /  / Questionable record] [Alberta /
   Kleskun Hills / ] [Cretaceous / Campanian / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Marsupials; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Marsupialia, Stagodontidae,
   Multituberculata

   Cimolodon (Multituberculata): [Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new species of Calomys (Rodentia: Sigmodontinae) from Eastern Brazil.
AU Bonvicino, Cibele R. (cibelerb@inca.gov.br) 
   De Oliveira, Joao A.
   Gentile, Rosana
SO Zootaxa
VL 2336
PS 19-35
PD 15 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02336p035.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB On the basis of combined analyses of karyotypic, molecular and
   morphologic data, we herein describe a new Calomys species collected in
   a transitional area between the Atlantic Forest and the Cerrado
   morphoclimatic domains of eastern Brazil. This new taxon differs from
   all other Brazilian Calomys species by its diploid number (2n=38), the
   lowest among Brazilian Calomys species, and by its yellowish snout.
   Phylogenetic analyses based on cytochrome b DNA suggest that this
   species belongs to the larger-bodied species group within Calomys,
   together with C. expulsus, C. callidus, C. callosus, and C. tocantinsi.
C1 Bonvicino, Cibele R.; Programa de Genetica, Instituto Nacional de
   Cancer, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Brazil.
EM cibelerb@inca.gov.br
RI Gentile, Rosana/C-3101-2013; Bonvicino, Cibele/O-3390-2014; Oliveira,
   Joao/I-3994-2012

PT J
AN ZOOR14603023271
DT Article
TI A new bomolochid copepod parasitic on bullseye puffer Sphoeroides
   annulatus (Jenyns) from Mexico, with reassignment of some species of
   Acantholochus Cressey and Hamaticolax Ho & Lin.
AU Morales-Serna, F.N. (neptali@ola.icmyl.unam.mx) 
   Gomez, S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2336
PS 36-50
PD 15 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02336p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new bomolochid copepod species, Acantholochus zairae (Cyclopoida:
   Bomolochidae), was found on the bullseye puffer fish Sphoeroides
   annulatus (Jenyns). It is the ninth species belonging to Acatholochus
   Cressey around the world and the third from the Mexican Pacific. Females
   of A. zairae sp. n. can be distinguished from Acantholochus spp. mainly
   by the presence of one seta (instead of two) on the second endopodal
   segment of leg 2 and by the strong, large claw of the maxilla.
   Acantholochus zairae sp. n. is attributable either to Acantholochus or
   to Hamaticolax Ho & Lin since no useful character to distinguish the
   genus Acantholochus from the genus Hamaticolax was found in the
   literature. We therefore suggest that species of the genus Acantholochus
   can only be distinguished from those of the genus Hamaticolax by the
   absence of the accessory process of the maxillipedal claw. Due to the
   above, three species of bomolochids hitherto placed in the genus
   Acantholochus (H. galeichthyos (Luque & Bruno) comb. nov., H.
   paralabracis (Luque & Bruno) comb. nov. and H. unisagittatus (Tavares &
   Luque) comb. nov.) are transferred to Hamaticolax and three species
   hitherto placed in the genus Hamaticolax (A. albidus (Wilson) comb.
   nov., A. australiensis (Byrnes) comb. nov. and A. venustus (Kabata)
   comb. nov.) are transferred to Acantholochus. In addition, keys to the
   females of both genera are provided.
C1 Morales-Serna, F.N.; Posgrado en Ciencias del Mar y Limnologia,
   Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Unidad Academica Mazatlan, Joel
   Montes Camarena s/n, Mazatlan 82040, Sinaloa, Mexico, Mexico.
EM neptali@ola.icmyl.unam.mx
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Acantholochus zairae [Piscean hosts / Sphoeroides annulatus / New
   parasite species] [North Pacific / Mexico / New species from piscean
   host]. 
   Sphoeroides annulatus [Crustacean parasites / Acantholochus zairae / New
   parasite species] [North Pacific / Mexico / New crustacean parasite
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Crustaceans; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Cyclopoida, Chordata,
   Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii, Tetraodontiformes,
   Tetraodontidae
OR Hamaticolax - Ho & Lin 2005 (Copepoda): [Emended diagnosis, P. 37; Key
   to species, Females, p. 38].

DT Article
TI A new species of Cyrtodactylus (Reptilia: Squamata: Geckkonidae) from
   Xizang Autonomous Region, China.
AU Shi, Lei (shileixj@126.com) 
   Zhao, Hui
SO Zootaxa
VL 2336
PS 51-60
PD 15 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02336p060.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Cyrtodactylus described from Nyemo County, Xizang
   Autonomous Region, China is here referred to a new species,
   Cyrtodactylus zhaoermii sp. nov. It is distinguished from all other
   Cyrtodactylus by the following characters: dorsal surface of the body
   with fine granules intermixed with larger sub-conical tubercles arranged
   into 20 more or less regular rows; proximal subdigital lamellae
   transversely expanded; 19[long dash]20 subdigital lamellae on toe IV;
   30[long dash]32 midbody ventral scales; most scales in femoral region
   small, granular, series of 12[long dash]14 enlarged femoral scales
   lacking pores; a series of precloacal pores (4) present in male; tail
   with distinct segments, large, posteriorly directed tubercles in whorls,
   numbering nine to ten per caudal annulus, three on each side and three
   to four on the dorsum, situated at the posterior edge of each annulus;
   subcaudals not transversely expanded. The new species is the fourth
   Cyrtodactylus known from Xizang Autonomous Region.
C1 Shi, Lei; Chengdu Institute of Biology, Chinese Academy of Science,
   Chengdu, 610041, China, China.
EM shileixj@126.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Cyrtodactylus zhaoermii [Xizang /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cyrtodactylus zhaoermii (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Xizang, P. 52].

TI Review of the Nomada roberjeotiana species-group (Hymenoptera: Apidae)
   of Russia, with description of new species.
AU Proshchalykin, Maxim Yu. (maxim@ibss.dvo.ru) 
   Lelej, Arkady S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2335
PS 1-15
PD 14 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02335p015.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The twelve species and two subspecies of Nomada roberjeotiana
   species-group from Russia are reviewed. Two new species, Nomada mitaii
   sp. nov. (Russia, Mongolia), and N. setteri sp. nov. (Russian Far East)
   are described and illustrated. A female lectotype is designated for
   Nomada palmeni Morawitz 1888. Nomada esana Tsuneki 1973 and N. hakusana
   hakusana Tsuneki 1973 are recorded for the first time from Russia.
   Nomada rufipes Fabricius 1793 is newly recorded from the Russian Far
   East and Kazakhstan, and N. roberjeotiana roberjeotiana is newly
   recorded from Mongolia. The distribution data for other species are
   enlarged. An identification key is presented for both sexes of this
   species-group.
C1 Proshchalykin, Maxim Yu.; Institute of Biology and Soil Science, Far
   Eastern Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok-22
   690022, Russia, Russia.
EM maxim@ibss.dvo.ru

   (Hymenoptera) / New record; systematics] [Russia /  / distribution]. 
   Nomada rufipes [Russia / Russian Far East / New record] [Kazakhstan /  /
   ]. 
   Nomada setteri [Russia /  / New species].

TI A new genus of oak gallwasps, Kinseyella Pujade-Villar & Melika, with a
   description of a new species from Mexico (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae:
   Cynipini).
AU Pujade-Villar, J. (jpujade@ub.edu) 
   Romero-Rangel, S.
   Chagoyan-Garcia, C.
   Equihua-Martinez, A.
   Estrada-Venegas, E.G.
   Melika, G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2335
PS 16-28
PD 14 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02335p028.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus of a cynipid oak gallwasp, Kinseyella (Hymenoptera:
   Cynipidae: Cynipini) is described from Mexico. Diagnostic characters and
   generic limits of the new genus are discussed in details. A new species,
   Kinseyella quercusobtusata is described, which induces galls on leaves
   of Quercus obtusata, an endemic Mexican oak. One earlier known species
   from Mexico was transferred to the newly established genus, Kinseyella
   lapiei (Kieffer), comb. nova. Diagnostic characters for separation of
   two species are also given.
C1 Pujade-Villar, J.; Departament de Biologia Animal, Facultat de Biologia,
   Universitat de Barcelona, Av. Diagonal, 645, 08028 Barcelona, Spain,
   Spain.
EM jpujade@ub.edu

   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America
DE Kinseyella quercusobtusata [Plant hosts / Quercus obtusata / New
   parasite species] [Mexico /  / New species from plant host]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae
OR Adleria lapiei - (Kieffer 1911) (Cynipidae): [Referred to, New genus
   Kinseyella, p. 23]. 
   Holcaspis weldi - Beutenmueller 1911 (Cynipidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 24; Status, As junior synonym of Kinseyella lapiei (Kieffer 1911), p.
   24].

   Cynipini, Type species Kinseyella quercusobtusata, p. 17]. 
   Kinseyella lapiei - (Kieffer 1911) (Cynipidae): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 19; Comb nov, Transferred from Adleria, p. 23]. 
   Kinseyella quercusobtusata - Pujade-Villar & Melika 2010 (Cynipidae):

AB Odontofroggatia is a non-pollinating fig wasp genus associated with a
   narrow range of host species (Ficus microcarpa and F. prasinicarpa). A
   new species, Odontofroggatia quinifuniculus Feng & Huang sp. nov., is
   described from specimens reared from F. microcarpa in Hainan province,
   China. A key for distinguishing species is presented. The holotype is
   deposited in Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences.

DT Article
TI A new species of Lachesilla Westwood (Psocoptera: Lachesillidae) in the
   andra group with a proposed classification of the andra group.
AU Mockford, Edward L. (elmockf@ilstu.edu) 
   Garcia Aldrete, Alfonso N.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2335
PS 49-58
PD 14 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02335p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe Lachesilla texana Mockford and Garca Aldrete, n. sp., with
   populations in northeastern Mexico, central and southern Texas, and
   Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Tennessee. Several minor
   differences are noted between the Smoky Mountains and the Texas-Mexican
   populations. We assign the new species to the andra group (Garca Aldrete
   1974) and in order to place it within this large and complex species
   group, we propose a classification of the group with designation of four
   subgroups based primarily on male external genitalic and paragenitalic
   structures. Probable apomorphies are noted for each of the subgroups.
C1 Mockford, Edward L.; School of Biological Sciences, Illinois State
   University, Normal, Illinois 61790/4120, USA, USA.
EM elmockf@ilstu.edu
SC Reproductive Biology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326

   Reproductive system; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA

   genitalic/paragenitalic structures / taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny
   / Cladistic relationships / ]. 
   Lachesilla texana [Mexico /  / New species] [Tennessee /  / ] [Texas / 
   / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

AB Two new species of Deferunda Distant, 1912 (Hemiptera: Fulgoroidae:
   Achilidae: Plectoderini), D. diana sp. nov. (China: Yunnan) and D. qiana

   (Araneae: Selenopidae) and redescription of Selenops scitus Muma, 1953
   from Mexico.
AU Valdez-Mondragon, Alejandro (lat_mactans@yahoo.com.mx) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2334
PS 47-58
PD 13 Jan 2010

AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02334p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Selenops Latreille, 1819 from Mexico are described:
   Selenops aztecus sp. nov. from the state of Veracruz, known only from a
   single male, and Selenops santibanezi sp. nov. from the state of Oaxaca,
   known from both sexes. Selenops scitus Muma, 1953, originally described
   only from the female holotype from Guerrero, Mexico is redescribed and
   the male of this species is described for the first time; new records of
   its distribution are given.

TI Contribution to the Nolinae (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae) fauna of North
   Thailand.
AU Laszlo, Gyula M. (laskology@t-online.hu) 
   Ronkay, Gabor
   Witt, Thomas J.
SO Esperiana
VL 15
PS 7-125, 440-461
PD 12 Januar 2010
PY 2010
NT Separate paginated plates pp. 440-461.
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Present paper is the first comprehensive summary of the Nolinae (sensu
   stricto) fauna of Northern Thailand. It contains the records of 127
   species occurring in this area, with the descriptions of 16 new genera
   and 46 new species, numerous new combinations, stati and synonyms. With
   11 colour plates and 58 genitalia figures.
C1 Laszlo, Gyula M.; Fadrusz utca 25, H-1114 Budapest, Hungary, Hungary.
EM laskology@t-online.hu
SC Zoology
SN 0949-4529

   Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; India

AN ZOOR14604027737
DT Article
TI New Orthosiini (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae, Hadeninae) species and genera
   from the wide sense Himalayan region.
AU Ronkay, Gabor (gronkay@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu) 
   Ronkay, Laszlo
   Gyulai, Peter
   Hacker, Hermann H.
SO Esperiana
VL 15
PS 127-221, 462-497
PD 12 Januar 2010
PY 2010
NT Separate paginated plates pp. 462-497.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new genera (Houlberthosia gen. nov., Megaegira gen. nov., Protegira
   gen. nov., and Nepalopolia gen. nov.), one new subgenus, Shaanxipolia
   subgen. nov., 33 new species (Panolis estheri spec. nov., Pseudopanolis
   stumpfi spec. nov., P. phalerina spec. nov., Orthosia decorata spec.
   nov., O. gozmanyi spec. nov., O. kalinini spec. nov., O. marmorata spec.
   nov., O. raui spec. nov., O. tiszka spec. nov., O. hoferi spec. nov., O.
   yelai spec. nov., O. ryrholmi spec. nov., O. luna spec. nov., O. volodia
   spec. nov., O. reserva spec. nov., Anorthoa semifusca spec. nov., A.
   polymorpha spec. nov., A. biborka spec. nov., Perigrapha subviolacea
   spec. nov., P. fuscopicta spec. nov., P. benedeki spec. nov., P.
   sechuana spec. nov., P. gyulaipeteri spec. nov., Harutaeographa odavissa
   spec. nov., H. stangelmaieri spec. nov., H. seibaldi spec. nov., H.
   loeffleri spec. nov., Megaegira monoglypha spec. nov., Orthopolia
   (Shaanxipolia) pallidiscripta spec. nov., Xylopolia quadra spec. nov.,
   X. macrobscura spec. nov., X. conspicienda spec. nov., Egira variabilis
   spec. nov., Nepalopolia egiromima spec. nov., N. gottfriedi spec. nov.
   and Pygmeopolia commixta spec. nov.) and 9 new subspecies (Pseudopanolis
   heterogyna funerea subspec. nov., Orthosia coniortota yeni subspec.
   nov., O. huberti marci subspec. nov., O. perfusca pekarskyi spec. nov.,
   Houlberthosia ornatissima speideli subspec. nov., Clavipalpula aurariae
   formosana subspec. nov., Xylopolia bella bellaetani subspec. nov.,
   Lithopolia confusa tsinlinga subspec. nov., and Kisegira regina rubra
   subspec. nov.) of the tribe Orthosiini are described from the wide sense
   Himalayan region. The status of Perigrapha circumducta pallescens
   DRAUDT, 1934 (stat. rev.) is clarified. With 18 colour plates and 60
   genitalia plates.
C1 Ronkay, Gabor; Szt. Istvan krt. 4, H-1137, Budapest, Hungary, Hungary.
EM gronkay@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 0949-4529

TI New Psaphidinae and Oncocnemidinae (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae) species and
   genera from the wide sense Himalayan region.
AU Ronkay, Gabor (gronkay@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu) 
   Ronkay, Laszlo
   Gyulai, Peter
   Hacker, Hermann H.
SO Esperiana
VL 15
PS 223-244, 498-505
PD 12 Januar 2010
PY 2010
NT Separate paginated plates pp. 498-505.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new genera (Benedekia, Allomeganephria, Fansipania and Beshkovietta
   gen. nov.), seven new species (Meganephria (Belosticta) becheri, M. (B.)
   uniformis, Benedekia gaudina, Allomeganephria hollogabori, Fansipania
   viridistellata, Beshkovietta indigena and Bryomima striata spp. nov.)
   and three new subspecies (Meganephria (Belosticta) cinerea morosa,
   Taipsaphida curiosa fujiani and Oncocnemis mixtazona honeyi sspp. nov.)
   of Psaphidinae (including Feraliini) and Oncocnemidinae from the
   Himalayan region are described. With 4 colour plates and 12 genitalia
   plates.

DT Article
TI New Xylenini (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae, Xyleninae) species and genera from
   the wide sense Himalayan region.
AU Ronkay, Gabor (gronkay@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu) 
   Ronkay, Laszlo
   Gyulai, Peter
   Hacker, Hermann H.
SO Esperiana
VL 15
PS 245-358, 506-547
PD 12 Januar 2010
PY 2010
NT Separate paginated plates pp. 506-547.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB 4 new Xylenini genera (Agasbogas, Gigatelorta, Gaurenoglaea and
   Cupreobole gen. nov.), 46 new species (Agasbogas viridis, Eupsilia
   metashyu, E. sulphurea, E, yoshimotoi, Lithophane fansipana, L.
   gonggashana, L. karakorina, Litholomia compromissa, Dryobotodes
   mikkolai, D. sinlaevi, Antivaleria peregovitsi, Daseutype secunda,
   Meganyctycia hanhuilini, Fabiania dolorosa, Isolasia intermixta, I.
   hunana, I. valentina, I. adriennei, P. barna, Plantea fidahusseini,
   Daseuplexia unicata, D. pittergabori, D. inexpecta, D. oroplexina, D.
   issekutzi, Dasypolia nekrasovi, D. sylvia, Polymixis chloromixis, P.
   muluki, Charanyctycia laura, C. maria, Evisa fantastica, Telorta
   fibigeri, Agrochola csoevarii, A. parki, A. humidalis, Gaurenoglaea
   misconspicua, G. alternata, Owadaglaea zillii, O. babicsi, Jodia
   nekrasovi, Elwesia orbiculosa, Hyalobole conistroides, H.
   medvegymihalyi, Cupreobole adrienneae and Tiliacea lineidistincta spp.
   nov.) and 7 new subspecies (Xylena apicimacula ayubia, Eupsilia
   transversa latipennata, Dryobotodes angusta weiserti, Potnyctycia
   porphyrea burmana, Agrochola sakabei continentalis, Nyctycia strigidisca
   vargai and Hyalobole albimacula nigrizonata subspp. nov.) from the
   Himalayan region are described. With 21 colour plates and 72 genitalia
   plates.

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Acontia Ochsenheimer, 1816 and the tribus
   Acontiini Guenee, 1841 (Old World) (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae Acontiinae)
   by H.H. Hacker, A. Legrain and M. Fibiger (Esperiana 14: 7-533).
   Corrigenda and supplementa.
AU Hacker, Hermann H. (hermann-heinrich.hacker@t-online.de) 
SO Esperiana
VL 15
PS 359-373, 550-551
PD 12 Januar 2010
PY 2010
NT Separate paginated plates pp. 550-551.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper contains some corrigenda of the Acontia revision, published
   in 2008, and results of several recent investigations made since the
   publication of the revision. It includes the description of two new
   species, Acontia hausmanni spec. nov. (Kenya), Acontia eburnea spec.
   nov. (Ivory Coast), and the following additional taxonomic changes:
   Acontia OCHSENHEIMER, 1816 = Hypercalymnia HAMPSON, 1910 syn. nov. tribe
   Acontiini = Hypercalymniini FIBIGER & LAFONTAINE, 2005 syn. nov. Acontia
   (Acontia) versicolorata HACKER nom. nov. (pro olivescens HAMPSON, 1910,
   praeocc.) Acontia (Uracontia) viettei HACKER nom. nov. (pro magnifica
   VIETTE, 1958, praeocc.) Acontia (Acontia) metaxantha HAMPSON, 1910 comb.
   nov. Acontia (Acontia) ampijoroa (VIETTE, 1965) comb. nov. Acontia
   (Acontia) laurenconi (VIETTE, 1965) comb. nov. Acontia (Acontia)
   malagasy (VIETTE, 1965) comb. nov. Acontia (Acontia) gloriosa (KENRICK,
   1917) comb. nov. Acontia (Acontia) transducta (VIETTE, 1958) comb. nov.
   Acontia (Acontia) splendida (ROTHSCHILD, 1924) comb. nov. Acontia
   (Acontia) accola (FELDER & ROGENHOFER, 1874) comb. nov. Acontia
   (Uracontia) magnifica (VIETTE, 1958) comb. nov. Acontia (Uracontia)
   melaphora (HAMPSON, 1910) comb. nov.
C1 Hacker, Hermann H.; Kilianstrasse 10, 95231 Bad Staffelstein, Germany,
   Germany.
EM hermann-heinrich.hacker@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0949-4529
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Available
   name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa

   Acontia (Emmelia) eburnea [Ivory Coast /  / New species].

   Noctuoidea, Noctuidae

   supplementa to revision by Hacker, Legrain & Fibiger 2008, p. 359; Syn
   nov, Hypercalymnia Hampson 1910, p. 361]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) accola - (Felder & Rogenhofer 1874) (Noctuidae): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Cirrhoedia, p. 364]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) ampijoroa - (Viette 1965) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Hypercalymnia, p. 363].

   Transferred from Hypercalymnia, p. 364]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) hausmanni (Noctuidae): [Sp nov, Kenya, P. 363]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) laurenconi - (Viette 1965) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Hypercalymnia, p. 364]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) malagasy - (Viette 1965) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Hypercalymnia, p. 364]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) metaxantha - (Hampson 1910) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Hypercalymnia, p. 361]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) olivescens - (Hampson 1910) (Noctuidae): [Preoccupied
   name replaced by, Acontia (Acontia) versicolorata, p. 362]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) splendida - (Rothschild 1924) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Carcharoda, p. 364]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) transducta - (Viette 1958) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Bocula, p. 364]. 
   Acontia (Acontia) versicolorata (Noctuidae): [Nom nov, For Acontia
   (Acontia) olivescens (Hampson 1910), p. 362]. 
   Acontia (Emmelia) eburnea (Noctuidae): [Sp nov, Ivory Coast, P. 367]. 
   Acontia (Emmelia) gagites - (Warren 1913) (Noctuidae): [Taxonomic
   position, P. 360]. 
   Acontia (Uracontia) magnifica - (Viette 1958) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Calpiformis, p. 365; Preoccupied name replaced by,
   Acontia (Uracontia) viettei, p. 365]. 
   Acontia (Uracontia) melaphora - (Hampson 1910) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Protarache, p. 365]. 
   Acontia (Uracontia) viettei (Noctuidae): [Nom nov, For Acontia
   (Uracontia) magnifica (Viette 1958), p. 365]. 
   Acontia melaena - (Hampson 1899) (Noctuidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Tarache, p. 367]. 
   Acontiini (Noctuidae): [Syn nov, Hypercalymniini Fibiger & Lafontaine
   2005, p. 361]. 
   Bocula transducta - Viette 1958 (Noctuidae): [Referred to, Acontia

PT J
AN ZOOR14604027747
DT Article
TI [Information on the species spectrum of the genus Creatonotos Huebner,
   1816 on the Arabian Peninsula with a revision of the Afrotropical
   Creatonotos leucanioides Holland, 1893 species group (Lepidoptera:
   Arctiidae. Spilosominae).]
FT Ueber das Artenspektrum der Gattung Creatonotos Huebner, 1816 auf der
   Arabischen Halbinsel mit einer Revision der afrotropischen Creatonotos
   leucanioides Holland, 1893-Artengruppe (Lepidoptera: Arctiidae.
   Spilosominae).
AU De Freina, Josef J. (defreina.j@online.de) 
SO Esperiana
VL 15
PS 423-431, 558-561
PD 12 Januar 2010
PY 2010
NT Separate paginated plates pp. 558-561.
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB The African and Arabian species of the genus Creatonotos HUBNER, 1816
   are revised. All species are illustrated and their distribution is
   discussed. All species in south-western Saudi Arabia and in Jemen are
   deemed to belong to the Afrotropical Creatonotos Ieucanioides HOLLAND,
   1893 group, while C. omanirana of FREINA, 2007 in north-east Oman
   belongs to the indoaustralian C. gangis group. Creatonotos leucanioides
   HOLLAND, 1893, the Arabian C. albidior WILTSHIRE, 1986 and the East
   African Creatonotos brunnipennis BARTEL, 1903 were found not to be
   distinguishable from each other on phenotypical features, including
   characters of the genitalia and androconial organs (coremata), and the
   distinguishing characters, as given in the descriptions of BARTEL (1903)
   and WILTSHIRE (1986) are not as distinct and stable as proposed.
   Further, molecular characters show only minimal differences between C.
   leucanioides and C. albidior, so that albidior at most can be regared as
   a subspecies of the former, recognisable by a paler coloration and
   reduced wing pattern. Consequently, albidior and brunnipennis are
   synonymised with leucanioides (syn. n.), the former relegated to
   subspecies level as C. leucanioides albidior (stat. n.).
C1 De Freina, Josef J.; Eduard Schmid-Str. 10, D-81541 Muenchen, Germany,
   Germany.
EM defreina.j@online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0949-4529
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Creatonotos [Africa /  / Systematics] [Asia / Arabia / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Arctiidae
OR Creatonotos - Huebner 1816 (Arctiidae). 
   Creatonotos albidior - Wiltshire 1986 (Arctiidae): [Downgraded to,
   Creatonotos leucanioides albidior, p. 425, Cited by author as Syn. nov.
   & stat. nov.]. 
   Creatonotos leucanioides - Holland 1893 (Arctiidae): [Syn nov,
   Creatonotos brunnipennis Bartel 1933, p. 425]. 
   Creatonotos leucanioides albidior - Wiltshire 1986 (Arctiidae):
   [Downgraded from, Creatonotos albidior, p. 425, Cited by author as Syn.
   nov. & stat. nov.].

DT Article
TI Review of the New World species of Salina (Collembola: Paronellidae)
   with bidentate mucro, including a key to all New World members of
   Salina.
AU Soto-Adames, Felipe N. (fsoto@illinois.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2333
PS 26-40
PD 12 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02333p040.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxonomic status of the four New World species of Salina
   MacGillivray with bidentate mucro is uncertain. The first two species to
   be described, S. bidentata (Handschin) and S. wolcotti Folsom, are so
   poorly described by modern standards that it is unclear if they
   represent distinct species or the same, colour-pattern variable forms.
   This contribution presents additions to the description of S. beta
   Christiansen & Bellinger based on the holotype, a redescription of S.
   bidentata and S. wolcotti based on freshly collected material from Costa
   Rica, Puerto Rico and Florida, USA, and description of a new species, S.
   thibaudi, from Costa Rica and Guadaloupe. Based on analysis of
   chaetotaxic patterns it is concluded that S. bidentata and S. wolcotti
   are distinct species, although it remains unclear if S. ventricolor
   Gruia, from Cuba is distinct from S. wolcotti. The discovery in Costa
   Rica and Guadaloupe of S. thibaudi, showing a distinct chaetotaxy, but
   with colour pattern identical to that illustrated in the original
   description of S. wolcotti, suggests that records of S. wolcotti outside
   Puerto Rico require verification. A key for the identification of all
   species of Salina reported from the Americas is provided.
C1 Soto-Adames, Felipe N.; Illinois Natural History Survey, University of
   Illinois, 1816 S. Oak Street, Champaign, Illinois 61820, USA, USA.
EM fsoto@illinois.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies
DE Salina [Land zones / America / Key to species] [ / New World /
   Systematics]. 
   Salina thibaudi [Costa Rica /  / New species] [Guadeloupe /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Collembola
OR Salina - MacGillivray (Collembola): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, Species reported from Americas, p. 37; Key to species,
   America, P. 38]. 
   Salina beta - Christiansen & Bellinger 1980 (Collembola):
   [Redescription, P. 35]. 
   Salina bidentata - (Handschin 1927) (Collembola): [Redescription, P.
   32]. 
   Salina thibaudi (Collembola): [Sp nov, Guadeloupe, P. 35]. 
   Salina wolcotti - Folsom 1927 (Collembola): [Redescription, P. 29]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023049

TI Revision of the Neotropical genus Cheiromyia Dyte (Diptera:
   Dolichopodidae).
AU Brooks, Scott E. (Scott.Brooks@AGR.GC.CA) 
   Cumming, Jeffrey M.
   Pollet, Marc A.A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2333
PS 41-58
PD 12 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02333p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Neotropical dolichopodine genus Cheiromyia is revised. The limits of
   the genus are redefined to include only those species with one or more
   elongate projections on the male postpedicel. Cheiromyia maculipennis
   (Van Duzee) is transferred to Paraclius Loew comb. nov. Cheiromyia is
   now known from Costa Rica south to Bolivia and the Brazilian Atlantic
   Forest, and includes the following five species: Cheiromyia bicornis
   Brooks sp. nov., C. brevitarsis Brooks sp. nov., C. laselva Brooks sp.
   nov., C. palmaticornis (Parent) and C. pennaticornis (Parent). A key to
   males is provided, as well as some remarks on related species of
   Paraclius.
C1 Brooks, Scott E.; Diptera Unit, Canadian National Collection of Insects,
   Invertebrate Biodiversity, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, K.W. Neatby
   Building, 960 Carling Avenue, Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.

PT J
AN ZOOR14603023054
DT Article
TI The first sexually dimorphic species of Oribatella (Acari, Oribatida,
   Oribatellidae) and a review of sexual dimorphism in the Brachypylina.
AU Behan-Pelletier, Valerie M. (Valerie.Behan-Pelletier@agr.gc.ca) 
   Eamer, Barbara
SO Zootaxa
VL 2332
PS 1-20
PD 11 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02332p020.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The oribatid mite genus Oribatella includes over 100 named species, none
   of which shows distinct sexual dimorphism in the octotaxic system of
   dermal glands. We propose a new species of this genus, Oribatella
   canadensis sp, nov., collected from dry soil habitats in western Canada,
   that shows distinct dimorphism in these dermal glands, the first record
   of this dimorphism in the Oribatelloidea. The posterior pair of glands
   in males, but not females, is enlarged and associated with a shallow,
   medial pit-tubercle complex, and is generally similar to convergent
   dimorphisms in some genera of Mochlozetidae (Oripodoidea), Mycobatidae
   (Ceratozetoidea) and Galumnidae (Galumnoidea). We describe this species
   based on adult and nymphal stages, and expand the diagnosis of the genus
   to accommodate the newly described immatures. We review the expression
   of sexual dimorphism in brachypyline oribatid mites and discuss its
   association with periodically dry habitats.
C1 Behan-Pelletier, Valerie M.; Systematic Entomology, Agriculture and
   Agri-Food Canada, K. W Neatby Building, 960 Carling Ave., Ottawa,
   Ontario, K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.
EM Valerie.Behan-Pelletier@agr.gc.ca
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Reproduction; Habitat; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; Canada
DE Brachypylina [Sex differences / Sexual dimorphism / ] [Habitat / Habitat
   characteristics / ]. 
   Oribatella canadensis [Alberta /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Brachypylina (Acari). 
   Oribatella canadensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Alberta, P. 3]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023054
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14603023056
DT Article
TI New species of aquatic oligochaetes (Annelida: Clitellata) from
   groundwaters in karstic areas of northern Spain, with taxonomic remarks
   on Lophochaeta ignota Stolc, 1886.
AU Rodriguez, Pilar (pilar.rodriguez@ehu.es) 
   Achurra, Ainara
SO Zootaxa
VL 2332
PS 21-39
PD 11 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02332p039.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB We describe two new species: Gianius navarroi n. sp. (Phallodrilinae)
   and Isochaetides gianii n. sp. (Tubificinae), which were discovered
   during investigations on the groundwater oligochaete fauna in northern
   Spain. The present study contributes to the knowledge of the stygobiont
   oligochaete species in the Iberian Peninsula, which includes 21 species
   so far. Mature specimens of Lophochaeta ignota Stolc, 1886 were also
   collected at some sites, and are used to supplement the limited
   description of the reproductive organs known for the species to date.
   Taxonomy of the genus Lophochaeta Stolc, 1886 is discussed.
C1 Rodriguez, Pilar; Department of Zoology and Animal Cell Biology, Faculty
   of Science and Technology, University of the Basque Country (UPV/EHU),
   Apdo. 644, Bilbao 48080, Spain, Spain.
EM pilar.rodriguez@ehu.es
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Gianius navarroi; Isochaetides gianii [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Oligochaeta
OR Gianius navarroi (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 22]. 
   Isochaetides gianii (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 25]. 
   Lophochaeta ignota - Stolc 1886 (Oligochaeta): [Redescription, P. 31]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023056
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14603023058
DT Article
TI A new species of suckermouth armored catfish, Pseudancistrus kwinti
   (Siluriformes: Loricariidae) from the Coppename River drainage, Central
   Suriname Nature Reserve, Suriname.
AU Willink, Philip W. (pwillink@fieldmuseum.org) 
   Mol, Jan H.
   Chernoff, Barry
SO Zootaxa
VL 2332
PS 40-48
PD 11 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02332p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of suckermouth armored catfish, Pseudancistrus kwinti, is
   described from the Coppename River, Suriname. It can be diagnosed from
   all other described Pseudancistrus by the following combination of
   characters: dentary papillae absent, mid-dorsal plate row complete,
   coloration mottled or with bars, hypertrophied odontodes along edge of
   snout, and weakly evertible cheek plates. It is only known from the
   Coppename River drainage within the Central Suriname Nature Reserve, a
   United Nations World Heritage Site, and one of the most pristine
   environments remaining on the planet. Mining, increased fishing
   pressure, and tourism threaten to change the region.
C1 Willink, Philip W.; The Field Museum/Fish Division, 1400 South Lake
   Shore Drive, Chicago, IL 60605, USA, USA.
EM pwillink@fieldmuseum.org
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Pseudancistrus kwinti [Surinam /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Loricariidae
OR Pseudancistrus kwinti (Loricariidae): [Sp nov, Surinam, P. 41]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023058
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14603023060
DT Article
TI Nothobranchius kadleci (Cyprinodontiformes: Nothobranchiidae), a new
   species of annual killifish from central Mozambique.
AU Reichard, Martin (reichard@ivb.cz) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2332
PS 49-60
PD 11 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02332p060.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Nothobranchius kadleci, a new African annual killifish species, is
   described from the drainages of the Save, Gorongose, Pungwe and Zangue
   Rivers in the Sofala Province of central Mozambique. Nothobranchius
   kadleci is similar to Nothobranchius furzeri from which it is
   distinguished by colouration (red pelvic fins, red lips, more extensive
   red colouration on body) and morphology (larger distance between
   pectoral and pelvic fins, shorter anal and dorsal fins, and shorter base
   of the anal fin). The currently known distribution of these two species
   is allopatric, with the N. kadleci range north of the N. furzeri range.
   Nothobranchius kadleci occurs sympatrically with Nothobranchius
   orthonotus and Nothobranchius rachovii, from which it can clearly be
   distinguished by different colour patterns of the fins and body, head
   shape and morphometric characteristics. A total of 12 populations were
   recorded between the northern bank of the Save River and southern bank
   of the Zambezi during collection trips in February 2008 and February
   2009.
C1 Reichard, Martin; Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic, Institute
   of Vertebrate Biology, Brno, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM reichard@ivb.cz
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Nothobranchius kadleci [Mozambique /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cyprinodontiformes, Aplocheilidae
OR Nothobranchius kadleci (Aplocheilidae): [Sp nov, Mozambique, P. 51]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023060
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14603023062
DT Article
TI Lithodes formosae, a new species of king crab from Taiwan (Crustacea:
   Decapoda: Lithodidae).
AU Ahyong, Shane T. (s.ahyong@niwa.co.nz) 
   Chan, Tin-Yam
SO Zootaxa
VL 2332
PS 61-68
PD 11 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02332p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of king crab is described from Taiwan, Lithodes formosae
   sp. nov. The new species resembles L. longispina Sakai, 1971, from
   Japan, L. megacantha Macpherson, 1991, from French Polynesia, and L.
   paulayi Macpherson & Chan, 2008, from Guam, in having long dorsal spines
   in adults, though it is most similar to L. paulayi. Lithodes formosae is
   distinguished from the aforementioned species primarily by differing
   branchial spine arrangement and proportional spine length. Comparison of
   partial cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI) gene sequences from L.
   formosae sp. nov., L. paulayi and L. longispina supports the specific
   status of the new species. Six species of Lithodidae are known from
   Taiwan, of which L. formosae sp. nov. is the first to be described as
   new from Taiwan.
C1 Ahyong, Shane T.; National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research,
   Private Bag 14901, Kilbirnie, Wellington, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM s.ahyong@niwa.co.nz
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Lithodes formosae [North Pacific / Taiwan / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Anomura
OR Lithodes formosae (Anomura): [Sp nov, Taiwan (marine), P. 62]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603023062
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14605036398
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Coscinocera Butler, 1879 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Coscinocera Butler, 1879 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 1
PS 5-8
PD 9 Januar 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Coscinocera BUTLER, 1879 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from the Aru archipelago (Indonesia, Maluku province) is
   described and both sexes are illustrated: C. aruensis n. sp., The
   holotype [male], ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk, is deposited in
   coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), and later, together with this
   collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen,
   Munich, Germany. C. aruensis n. sp. closely resembles the Australian C.
   hercules (MISKIN, 1876). However, C. aruensis n. sp. can be readily
   distinguished on external characters, particularly the form of the
   forewing ocelli as well as on the male genitalia. The preimaginal
   instars of the new taxon are unknown to me.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Coscinocera aruensis [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Coscinocera aruensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 5].

TI A new species of the genus Salassa Moore, 1859 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae, Salassinae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Salassa Moore, 1859 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae,
   Salassinae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Kitching, Ian J.
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 1
PS 9-11
PD 9 Januar 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Salassa MOORE, 1859 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) is described and both sexes figured: S. arianae n. sp.,
   from the Chinese provinces of Shaanxi (type series), Sichuan and Hubei.
   The holotype [male] (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN) is deposited in coll.
   Museum WITT, Munich, which later, together with this collection, will be
   incorporated into the Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich,
   Germany. The new species has the most northern known distribution within
   the genus. The preimaginal instars are unknown.

TI Three new taxa of the miranda-group of the genus Loepa Moore, 1859
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Drei neue Taxa der miranda-Gruppe der Gattung Loepa Moore, 1859
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Kitching, Ian J.
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 1
PS 12-18
PD 9 Januar 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new taxa of the miranda-species group of the genus Loepa MOORE,
   1859 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) are described and figured: Loepa
   paramiranda n. sp. from Sikkim and Nepal, Loepa orientomiranda n. sp.
   from N. Vietnam and Loepa orientomiranda mirella n. ssp. from N.
   Thailand (= type series/locality (TL)) and SW Yunnan (China). All
   holotype [male] [male] are ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk, in coll.
   Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later, together with this
   collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen,
   Munich, Germany. Within the genus all the new taxa belong to the
   miranda-group (sensu NAUMANN 1995: 82). In addition, the lectotypes of
   both Loepa miranda MooRE, 1865 and Loepa damartis JORDAN, 1911 are
   designated.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.

AB A new species of the genus Loepa MOORE, 1859 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae)
   from Borneo (Sabah, Sarawak (both East Malaysia), Brunei, Kalimantan
   (Indonesia)), Loepa martinii n. sp., is described and both sexes

   with this collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen
   Muenchen, Munich, Germany. Within the genus, the new species belongs to
   the katinka-group (sensu NAUMANN 1995: 82).
