DT Article
TI New taxa of the genus Loepa Moore, 1859 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Neue Taxa der Gattung Loepa Moore, 1859 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 1
PS 23-35
PD 9 Januar 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nine new taxa of the genus Loepa MOORE, 1859 (Lepidoptera: Satumiidae)
   are described and figured: Loepa diehli n. sp. from Sumatra (Indonesia),
   Loepafinnackermanni n. sp. from S. Sulawesi (Indonesia: Sulawesi
   Tenggara and Sulawesi Selatan provinces), Loepa peggyae n. sp. from
   Vietnam, Loepapeggyae hainanensis n. ssp. from the island of Hainan
   (China), Loepa siamensis n. sp. from N Thailand (type locality (TL)),
   Laos, Vietnam, Yunnan (SW China), Loepa siamensis malayensis n. ssp.
   from W-Malaysia (TL), S-Myanmar and Cambodia, Loepa nepalensis n. sp.
   from Nepal, Loepa diffunorientalis n. sp. from Vietnam and Loepa
   diffunoccidentalis n. sp. from N Myanmar and Bhutan. All holotype [male]
   [male] ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk, are deposited in coll. Museum
   WITT, Munich (Germany), and later, together with this collection, will
   be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany.
   In addition, L. javanica MELL, 1939 stat. nov. is raised to full species
   status. All these taxa belong to the katinka-group (sensu NAUMANN 1995:
   82) of the genus. A complete checklist of the genus is also given..
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.

TI New taxa of the genus Cricula Walker, 1855 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).

   from Sumatra (Indonesia), Cricula elaezioborneensis n. sp. from Borneo,
   Cricula elaeziopahangensis n. sp. from W Malaysia, Cricula
   kalimantanensis n. sp. from Borneo (but presently known only from
   Kalimantan, Indonesia), Cricula trifenestratoides n. sp. from W Yunnan

   australovietnama n. sp. from S Vietnam and Cricula vietnama hunana n.
   ssp. from Hunan province (S China). All holotype [male] [male] ex coll.
   Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk, are deposited in coll. Museum WITT, Munich
   (Germany), and later, together with this collection, will be included in

DT Article
TI Two new species and descriptive notes for five Pseudosinella species
   (Hexapoda: Collembola: Entomobryidae) from West Virginian (USA) caves.
AU Soto-Adames, Felipe N. (fsoto@illinois.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2331
PS 1-34
PD 8 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02331p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The present contribution gives a taxonomic account of the members of the
   springtail genus Pseudosinella Schaffer, collected during the 2004[long
   dash]2006 expeditions organized by Daniel Fong and David Culver to caves
   of eastern and southern West Virginia. These expeditions are part of an
   ongoing long-term effort to develop a complete inventory of the cave
   fauna of the state. The samples examined include seven species of
   Pseudosinella, two of which, P. josemarii sp. nov. and P. meganporteri
   sp. nov. are new to science. For five previously named species
   descriptive notes are given emphasizing new or incompletely described
   characters such as the dorsal and ventral head chaetotaxy, number of
   teeth in the ungulum of the maxilla, presence or absence of setae a6 on
   the first abdominal segment, and lateral chaetotaxy of the fourth
   abdominal segment. Detailed analysis of the dorsal chaetotaxy of the
   head shows that Gisin's RST system of nomenclature confounds the
   identity of some macrosetae, hence, a new nomenclature system,
   denominated AMS, is proposed to more consistently identify macrosetae
   across all Lepidocyrtini. In addition, a system is proposed to describe
   variation in number of postlabial setae, their shape and ornamentation.
C1 Soto-Adames, Felipe N.; University of Illinois, Illinois Natural History
   Survey, 1816 South Oak Street, Champaign, IL 61820, USA, USA.
EM fsoto@illinois.edu
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Habitat; Subterranean
   habitat; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Pseudosinella [Cave habitat /  / Systematics] [West Virginia / East &
   south / ]. 
   Pseudosinella josemarii; Pseudosinella meganporteri [West Virginia /  /

TI A revision of the New Zealand click beetle genus Amychus Pascoe 1876
   (Coleoptera: Elateridae: Denticollinae): with a description of a new
   species from the Three Kings Islands.
AU Marris, John W.M. (john.marris@lincoln.ac.nz) 
   Johnson, Paul J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2331
PS 35-56
PD 8 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02331p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The New Zealand endemic click beetle genus Amychus Pascoe (Elateridae:
   Denticollinae: Ctenicerini) is revised. Three species are recognised: A.
   candezei Pascoe, A. granulatus (Broun) and A. manawatawhi, sp. nov. All
   species are described or redescribed from the adults. The larva of each
   species and the pupa of A. candezei are described for the first time.
   Lectotypes are designated for A. candezei Pascoe and A. granulatus
   (Broun). Keys to species for adults and larvae are given. The
   phylogenetic placement of the genus, biology and conservation of the
   species are discussed.

TI Taxonomical and biological notes on Neotropical Apiomerini (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Reduviidae: Harpactorinae).
AU Gil-Santana, Helcio R. (helciogil@uol.com.br) 
   Forero, Dimitri
SO Zootaxa
VL 2331
PS 57-68
PD 8 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02331p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB New occurrences of Apiomerini species are recorded: Apiomerus arnaui
   Costa Lima, Seabra & Hathaway and Apiomerus gallegoi Costa Lima, Seabra
   & Hathaway from Brazil, and Heniartes scutellatus Wygodzinsky from
   Surinam. Remarks on the color variation of Agriocleptes bahianus
   Wygodzinsky, Apiomerus evanidus Distant, Apiomerus gallegoi, and
   Heniartes scutellatus are given. Based on color variation within a
   single population and the absence of structural differences between the
   two forms, Heniartes australis Wygodzinsky is placed in synonymy with
   Heniartes jaakkoi Wygodzinsky. Observations on sticky substances on fore
   legs of live nymphal instars of Apiomerus mutabilis and Heniartes
   jaakkoi are provided. Occurrence of eggs of Tachinidae on adults of
   Heniartes jaakkoi and Apiomerus mutabilis Costa Lima, Seabra & Hathaway
   is recorded for the first time for the tribe Apiomerini.

PM 19793745
DT Article
TI Symbiosis-dependent gene expression in coral-dinoflagellate association:
   cloning and characterization of a P-type H+-ATPase gene.
AU Bertucci, Anthony (zoccola@centrescientifique.mc) 
   Tambutte, Eric
   Tambutte, Sylvie
   Allemand, Denis
   Zoccola, Didier
SO Proceedings of the Royal Society Biological Sciences Series B
VL 277
IS 1678
PS 87-95
PD January 7 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 25
AB We report the molecular cloning of a H+-ATPase in the symbiotic
   dinoflagellate, Symbiodinium sp. previously suggested by pharmacological
   studies to be involved in carbon-concentrating mechanism used by
   zooxanthellae when they are in symbiosis with corals. This gene encodes
   a protein of 975 amino acids with a calculated mass of about 105 kDa.
   The structure of the protein shows a typical P-type H+-ATPase structure
   (type IIIa plasma membrane H+-ATPases) and phylogenetic analyses show
   that this new proton pump groups with diatoms in the Chromoalveolates
   group. This Symbiodinium H+-ATPase is specifically expressed when
   zooxanthellae are engaged in a symbiotic relationship with the coral
   partner but not in free-living dinoflagellates. This proton pump,
   therefore, could be involved in the acidification of the perisymbiotic
   space leading to bicarbonate dehydration by carbonic anhydrase activity
   in order to supply inorganic carbon for photosynthesis as suggested by
   earlier studies. To our knowledge, this work provides the first example
   of a symbiosis-dependent gene in zooxanthellae and confirms the
   importance of H+-ATPase in coral-dinoflagellate symbiosis.
C1 Bertucci, Anthony; Ctr Sci Monaco, Ave St Martin, Monaco 98000, Monaco.
EM zoccola@centrescientifique.mc
RI Zoccola, Didier/A-6157-2009; Bertucci, Anthony J.B./O-6974-2014;
   Zoccola, Didier/A-5997-2009
OI Zoccola, Didier/0000-0002-1524-8098; Bertucci,
   Anthony/0000-0001-5727-7228
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Cell Biology; Biochemistry
   &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0962-8452
BD Cytology; Cell membranes; Biochemistry; Proteins; Genetics; Associations
DE Stylophora pistillata [Mutualism / Symbiodinium (Protozoa) / Symbiosis;
   gene cloning; characterization & function]. 
   Symbiodinium [Membrane transport systems / Proton pump / Cnidarian
   mutualists; symbiosis] [Nucleic acids / P-type H+-ATPase gene cloning &
   characterization / ] [Enzymes / ATPase / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ]
   [Mutualism / Stylophora pistillata (Cnidaria) / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates; Protozoans

   Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea, Dinoflagellida
OR Stylophora pistillata (Scleractinia).

DT Article
TI A checklist of names in Alona Baird 1843 (Crustacea: Cladocera:
   Chydoridae) and their current status: an analysis of the taxonomy of a
   lump genus.
AU Van Damme, Kay (kay.vandamme@ugent.be) 
   Kotov, Alexey A.
   Dumont, Henri J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2330
PS 1-63
PD 7 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02330p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We discuss current progress with the revision of Alona Baird, 1843
   (Crustacea: Cladocera: Chydoridae), the largest cladoceran lump genus.
   We present the first inventory of these Aloninae since the 1970's and
   include an updated checklist of names, with comments on the current
   status and position of each taxon. We discuss validity, affinities and
   synonymy of ca. 240 names, including subspecies and varieties. Recent
   taxonomic shifts have lead to a better delineation of natural groups in
   the Aloninae but the Alona puzzle remains incomplete. The majority of
   taxa are grouped into species-complexes or separate genera. We count 14
   Aloninae genera, now considered valid, that were split from Alona. The
   status of a significant portion remains unclear, due to poor original
   descriptions and/or loss of type material. Even with detailed
   morphological descriptions, the phylogenetic position of many Aloninae
   remains unsettled. Analysis of Alona taxonomy based on the checklist
   shows historical trends and long periods of instability in the
   systematics of these micro-crustaceans.
C1 Van Damme, Kay; Department of Biology, Ghent University, K.L.
   Ledeganckstraat 35, B-9000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM kay.vandamme@ugent.be

   27].

TI Two new Pristimantis (Anura: Terrarana: Strabomantidae) from the Sierra
   de Perija, Venezuela.
AU Barrio-Amoros, Cesar L. (cesarlba@yahoo.com) 
   Rojas-Runjiac, Fernando
   Barros, Tito R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2329
PS 1-21
PD 6 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02329p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Pristimantis are described from Cerro Las Antenas, on
   the Venezuelan versant of the Sierra de Perija, a region that is being
   rapidly destroyed by extensive cultivation and civil unrest. The first
   species (P. lassoalcalai sp. nov.) has dirty-white spots surrounded by
   black in the groin and on the hidden surfaces of the hind limbs[long
   dash]a characteristic shared by members of the "lentiginosus" group
   (Rivero 1982) from the Cordillera de Merida[long dash]and marbled to
   reticulated venter. The second species (P. rivasi sp. nov.) is currently
   the largest member of the genus known from Perija, and presents
   conspicuous cranial crests. The two new species are assigned to the P.
   unistrigatus species group.

   Merida, Venezuela, Venezuela.

DT Article
TI Henricia pumila sp. nov.: a brooding seastar (Asteroidea) from the
   coastal northeastern Pacific.
AU Eernisse, Douglas J. (deernisse@fullerton.edu) 
   Strathmann, Megumi F.
   Strathmann, Richard R.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2329
PS 22-36
PD 6 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02329p036.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 10
AB A small species of the seastar genus Henricia Gray, 1840 occurs along
   the cool temperate Pacific coast of North America from near Sitka,
   Alaska to just south of Ensenada, Baja California, Mexico. Its small
   adult size, mottled aboral colors, and benthic external brooding
   reproductive mode have long been noted, but it has never been formally
   separated from the larger, free-spawning Henricia leviuscula (Stimpson,
   1857), with which it has been confused. Here we amplify the description
   of H. leviuscula, based on examination of the holotype and new
   specimens, and restrict it to only one of several similar species that
   co-occur in Puget Sound and vicinity. We also describe the small mottled
   brooder as Henricia pumila sp. nov., characterize its distribution, and
   contrast its morphology with H. leviuscula based on the arrangement of
   marginal plates and the microanatomy of aboral spines.
C1 Eernisse, Douglas J.; Department of Biological Science, California State
   University, Fullerton, CA 92834-6850, USA, USA.
EM deernisse@fullerton.edu
RI Eernisse, Douglas/B-5016-2011
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326

   Ocean

   [ / Mexico / ] [ / USA, California / ] [ / USA, Washington / ]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Stelleroidea, Asteroidea
OR Henricia leviuscula - (Stimpson 1857) (Asteroidea): [Redescription, P.

   Henricia pumila (Asteroidea): [Sp nov, USA, Washington (marine), P. 30].

AB The new lysianassoid amphipod family Hirondelleidae is established and
   the deep-sea scavenging genus Hirondellea is reported from Australian
   waters for the first time. Five new species are described: H. diamantina
   sp. nov.; H. endeavour sp. nov.; H. franklin sp. nov.; H. kapala sp.
   nov.; and H. naturaliste sp. nov. Anonyx wolfendeni Tattersall is
   transferred into Hirondellea.

TI A new species of the genus Gekko Laurenti (Squamata: Sauria: Gekkonidae)
   from Vietnam with remarks on G. japonicus (Schlegel).
AU Roesler, Herbert (ziegler@koelnerzoo.de) 
   Nguyen, Truong Quang
   Van Doan, Kien
   Ho, Cuc Thu
   Nguyen, Tao Thien
   Ziegler, Thomas
SO Zootaxa
VL 2329
PS 56-68
PD 6 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02329p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe a new species of the gekkonid genus Gekko from northern
   Vietnam on the basis of four specimens from Lang Son and Lao Cai
   provinces. Gekko canhi sp. n. is distinguished from the remaining
   congeners by the combination of the following characters: body size
   moderate (SVL < 100 mm); supralabials 12[long dash]14, infralabials
   10[long dash]13; nares in contact with rostral, internasal single,
   nasals 3; interorbitals 47[long dash]50; dorsal tubercle rows 10[long
   dash]13; scales between mental and cloacal slit 205[long dash]229;
   midbody scales 164[long dash]170; subdigital lamellae below first toe
   13[long dash]16, below fourth toe 14[long dash]17; extensive webbing
   between fingers and toes minimal; tibial tubercles present; precloacal
   pores 5; postcloacal tubercles 2[long dash]3; tail round, not thickened
   at base; caudal tubercles present; subcaudals enlarged. We also provide
   new information on the taxonomy and distribution of G. japonicus in
   Vietnam.

TI Studies on Prionoceridae (Coleoptera: Cleroidea). II. A revision of the
   genus Prionocerus Perty, 1831.
AU Geiser, Michael (michael.geiser@stud.unibas.ch) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2328
PS 1-48
PD 5 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02328p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Prionocerus Perty, 1831 is revised. Eight species are
   recognised: P. coeruleipennis Perty, 1831 (= P. coeruleipennis var.
   diversicollis Pic, 1920, n. syn.); P. bicolor Redtenbacher, 1868 (= P.
   pertii Castelnau, 1836, n. syn.); P. opacipennis (Pic, 1920)
   (transferred from Idgia Castelnau, 1836); P. viridiflavus Geiser, 2007
   and four new species: P. paiensis n. sp. (Thailand); P. malaysiacus n.
   sp. (Malaysia); P. championi n. sp. (Indonesia) and P. wittmeri n. sp.
   (Indonesia). All previous synonymies of taxa under P. coeruleipennis and
   P. bicolor could be confirmed through study of the relevant types.
   Prionocerus pertii Castelnau, 1836 was found to be conspecific with P.
   bicolor Redtenbacher, 1868, but this senior synonymy was submitted to
   the ICZN proposing it as nomen oblitum. Prionocerus thibetanus
   Obenberger, 1918 is newly synonymised with Idgia viridescens Gorham,
   1895. Prionocerus huegeli Redtenbacher, 1868 and P. hirtus Walker, 1871
   are confirmed to belong to Idgia, the latter has to be treated as a
   nomen dubium. The infrageneric phylogeny of Prionocerus, its
   relationships to other Prionoceridae, as well as its life history,
   ecology and biogeography are discussed.
C1 Geiser, Michael; Natural History Museum, Entomology, Augustinergasse 2,
   CH-4001 Basel, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM michael.geiser@stud.unibas.ch
SC Developmental Biology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Life cycle and
   development; Evolution; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Prionocerus [Life cycle / Life history / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Ecology / 
   / ] [Zoogeography /  / ]. 
   Prionocerus championi; Prionocerus wittmeri [Indonesia /  / New
   species]. 
   Prionocerus malaysiacus [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Prionocerus paiensis [Thailand /  / New species].

   Melyridae

   Idgia opacipennis - Pic 1920 (Melyridae): [Referred to, Prionocerus, p.

   Idgia viridescens - Gorham 1895 (Melyridae): [Syn nov, Idgia thibetana
   (Obenberger 1918), p. 42].

DT Article
TI The genus Tapiena Bolivar (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae: Phaneropterinae;
   Holochlorini), with description of three new species from China.
AU Liu, Chun-Xiang (lkang@ioz.ac.cn) 
   Kang, Le
SO Zootaxa
VL 2328
PS 49-64
PD 5 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02328p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Tapiena Bolivar, 1906 (type species Tapeina acutangula Brunner von
   Wattenwyl, 1878) (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae) is reviewed from China. A
   list and an identification key to ten species of Tapiena from China are
   given. Three new species are described: T. parapentagona sp. n., T.
   bilobata sp. n., and T. stridulous sp. n.. The previously unknown female
   of T. spinicaudata Liu & Xia, 1996 are described for the first time.
   Based on the examination of male stridulatory area, some known species
   are redescribed. Important and necessary illustrations, a distribution
   map, and discussion on distribution of Tapiena are provided.
C1 Liu, Chun-Xiang; Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences,
   Beijing 1000080, China, China.

DT Article
TI The goblin spiders of the genus Opopaea (Araneae, Oonopidae) in Hainan
   Island, China.
AU Tong, Yanfeng (lisq@ioz.ac.cn) 
   Li, Shuqiang
SO Zootaxa
VL 2327
PS 23-43
PD 4 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02327p043.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Seven species of Opopaea are recognized from Hainan Island, China. Four
   species are found to be new to science: Opopaea diaoluoshan sp. nov.
   (male/female), Opopaea furcula sp. nov. (male/female), Opopaea sanya sp.
   nov. (male) and Opopaea vitrispina sp. nov. (male/female). One species,
   Opopaea sauteri Brignoli, 1974 is firstly recorded from this area. All
   of them, including the two previously known species, Opopaea cornuta Yin
   & Wang, 1984 and Opopaea gibbifera Tong & Li, 2008, are diagnosed and
   illustrated. A key to all the seven species of Hainan Island is
   provided.

   Beijing, 100101, China, China.

TI Taxonomy of European Damaeidae (Acari: Oribatida) III. Species of the
   Kunstidamaeus tenuipes (Michael, 1885) group, with a description of
   Kunstidamaeus fraterculus n. sp. from East Slovakia.
AU Miko, Ladislav (ladislav.miko@ec.europa.eu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2327
PS 51-64
PD 4 Jan 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02327p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Modern redescriptions and new diagnoses of three species of genus
   Kunstidamaeus, belonging to the "tenuipes" group - K. tenuipes (Michael,
   1885), K. granulatus (Willmann, 1951), K. nivalis (Kulczynski, 1902) are
   given. Another species of this group, K. fraterculus n.sp., is
   described, based on individuals from Drevenk hill in East Slovakia. The
   group is characterized by relatively short, at least partly barbed,
   slightly club-shaped sensillus.

   9, 1160 Auderghem, Brussels, Belgium, Belgium.

DT Article
TI Two new endemic bimucronate Candoninae-genera from the Upper Pliocene of
   Metohia (Ostracoda, Crustacea).
AU Krstic, N. (n_krstic@ptt.rs) 
   Keyser, D.
SO Bulletin Academie Serbe des Sciences et des Arts Classe des Sciences
   Mathematiques et Naturelles Sciences Naturelles
VL 140
IS 46
PS 105-129
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Aberrant candonid species from Upper Pliocene sediments of Metohia are
   described and illustrated. Three species, one of them new, are closely
   related to the extant Candona bimucronata Klie and belong to the genus
   Carpathocandona n. gen. Two other new species are referred to the genus
   Metohicandona n.gen. An additional species is tentatively placed in
   Carpathocandona owing to the presence of two extensions (mucrons) on the
   lower part of the anterior and posterior-ventral margins.
C1 Krstic, N.; Djoka Vojvodica 6, 11000 Beograd, Serbia, Serbia.

DT Article
TI Nature Reserves Grady Nad Moszczenica and Grady Nad Linda - refuges of
   forest malacofauna in Central Poland.
AU Sulikowska-Drozd, Anna (sulik@biol.uni.lodz.pl) 
SO Folia Malacologica
VL 18
IS 2
PS 59-69
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In 2007 and 2009 two forest nature reserves situated in the environs of
   Lodz, Central Poland, were sampled by visual search and sieving litter
   samples to produce complete lists of terrestrial gastropods. Four sites
   representing various plant communities were searched in each reserve
   (Tilio-Carpinetum typicum, Tilio-Carpinetum stachyetosum,
   Fraxino-Alnetum, Ribeso nigri-Alnetum). The resulting material included
   3,217 speci- mens representing 44 species of gastropods (including 38
   terrestrial) and bivalves (Pisidium sp.). Thirty eight gastropod species
   were recorded from Grady nad Moszczenica (among them five slugs and four
   freshwater snails); and 35 from Grady nad Linda (among them six slugs
   and four freshwater snails). The richest sites (Fraxino-Alnetum in Grady
   nad Moszczenica and Ribeso nigri-Alnetum in Grady nad Linda) harboured
   27 and 26 terrestrial gastropod species, respectively. Some species were
   recorded for the first time in the region, namely: Acicula polita
   (Hartmann), Vertigo alpestris Alder and Clausilia cruciata (Studer). The
   rich malacofauna with three coexisting clausiliid species (Alinda
   biplicata (Montagu), Ruthenica filograna (Rossmassler) and Clausilia
   cruciata (Studer)) in Grady nad Moszczenica indicates a small degree of
   habitat destruction in the nature reserve.
C1 Sulikowska-Drozd, Anna; Department of Invertertebrate Zoology and
   Hydrobiology, University of Lodz, Banacha 12/16, 90-237 Lodz, Poland,
   Poland.
EM sulik@biol.uni.lodz.pl
OI Drozd, Anna/0000-0002-2865-7130
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry
SN 1506-7629

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   area / New record]. 
   Mollusca [Habitat preference / Habitat associations / ] [Forest and
   woodland / Forest nature reserves / faunal list] [Poland / Lodz area /

TI Taxonomic study of two new species of the genus Mogheia (Lopez Neyera,
   1994) from Skyes.
AU Yasin, Shah Shabbir Ahmed
SO International Journal of Parasitology Research
VL 2
IS 2
PS 8-11
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.bioinfo.in/journalcontent.php?id=211
AW http://www.bioinfo.in/uploadfiles/12843149302_2_3_IJPR.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Mogheia, Lopez-Neyra in 1994 i.e., Mogheia
   yasini n.sp. and Mogheia shahadensis n.sp. were collected from Turdoides
   malcomi (Skyes) from different part of Maharashtra State India. The
   present parasites are differ from all the known species of the genus
   Mogheia, Lopez-Neyra,1994 in having length of worm, number and shape of
   testes, shape of cirrus pouch, shape of ovary, position of vagina and
   structure of vitellaria.

   College of Science, Yeola, Nashik, 423401, India, India.

TI Taxonomic Observation of the Caryophyllidean Tapeworm Lytocestus Cohn,

AU Bhure, D.B. (draj_bhure@yahoo.co.in)

   Shaikh, K.M.

PS 1-6
PD 2010

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Lytocestus Cohn, 1908 i.e. Lytocestus
   follicularae Sp.Nov. and Lytocestus osmanabadensis Sp.Nov. were
   collected from Clarias batrachus (Linneus, 1758) from different part of
   Maharashtra State India. The present parasites are differ from all the
   known species of the genus Lytocestus Cohn, 1908 in having length of
   worm, number and shape of testes, shape of cirrus pouch, shape of ovary,
   position of vagina and structure of vitellaria.

DT Article
TI Description of Acrobeloides uberrinus Anderson, 1965 and A. syrtisus
   Yeates, 1967 (Rhabditida: Cephalobidae) with a discussion of the
   taxonomic status of A. tricorns (Thorne, 1925) Thorne, 1937 and A.
   setosus Brzeski, 1962.
AU Bostrom, S. (sven.bostrom@nrm.se) 
   Holovachov, O.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 13
IS 2
PS 97-106
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A population identified as belonging to Acrobeloides uberrinus Anderson,
   1965 is described from sand with some organic material in Senegal, and a
   population of Acrobeloides syrtisus Yeates, 1967 is described from the
   sand dunes of the type locality in New Zealand. Both species are studied
   under light microscopy (LM) and A. uberrinus is also studied under
   scanning electron microscopy (SEM), providing some new information on
   the variability of the species. The two populations are compared with
   their respective original descriptions, other populations of A.
   uberrinus, and with the closely related species A. setosus Brzeski, 1962
   and A. tricornis (Thorne, 1925) Thorne, 1937. Acrobeloides setosus, A.
   uberrinus and A. syrtisus are considered to he synonyms of A. tricornis.
C1 Bostrom, S.; Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Swedish Museum of
   Natural History, Box 50007, SE-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden, Sweden.
EM sven.bostrom@nrm.se
SC Zoology
SN 1139-5192
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Synonymy

ST Animalia, Nematoda

PT J

DT Article
TI Monochida from Japan.
AU Ahmad, W. (ahmadwasim57@yahoo.co.in) 
   Mizukubo, T.
   Yoshida, M.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 13
IS 2
PS 123-156
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper deals with the description/record of 18 species, four
   new and 14 known, representing the Order Mononchida from Japan. Clarkus
   enigmatus sp. n. has body 1.54-2.07 mm long, lip region wide and offset,
   buccal cavity slightly asymmetrical and 32-36 x 17-19 [mu]m, large
   dorsal tooth with its apex at 84-87% of stoma length from base,
   subventral ridge slightly dentate at its proximal end, female genital
   system amphidelphic, echinulate eggs, and tail conical elongate and
   curved ventrad. Prionchulus japonicus sp. n. has body 1.58-1.84 mm long,
   lip region offset and wider than the adjoining body, buccal cavity 34-36
   x 19-20 [mu]m, dorsal tooth apex at 80-83% from base of buccal cavity,
   subventral ridges with 10-13 moderately developed denticles, amphids at
   level of the anterior end of the buccal cavity, pars refringens vaginae
   with three drop-shaped sclerotized pieces, uterine egg 117 x 74[mu]m,
   tail 104-128 [mu]m long and curved ventrad with a dorsal depression near
   the terminus and sharply pointed tip. Mylonchulus monhystera sp. n. has
   body 1.08-1.14 mm long, lip region offset and distinctly wider than the
   adjoining body, buccal cavity 25-28 x 15-16 [mu]m, dorsal tooth large
   and claw-like with its apex at 80-84% from base of buccal cavity,
   subventral teeth well developed, ventrosublateral denticles arranged in
   5 or 6 rows, female genital system mono-prodelphic with very small
   post-uterine sac, V = 70-75, tail 25-35 [mu]m long, curved ventrad, and
   often with sudden narrowing near terminus giving a digitate appearance,
   and caudal glands well developed with terminal spinneret. Miconchus
   nipponi sp. n. has body 1.87-2.21 mm long, lip region offset by
   depression, amphid aperture at level with the middle of the
   praeparietale of buccal cavity, dorsal and subventral teeth similar in
   shape and size and located at 30-33% from base of stoma, female genital
   system amphidelphic, three well developed, blister-like vulval papillae
   present anterior and occasionally also posterior to vulva, spicules
   slightly curved ventrad and about 1.5 times the body diameter long,
   gubernaculum with its distal end appearing as two dorsally bent
   finger-like projections, lateral guiding pieces with bifid distal end,
   11 well developed, regularly spaced ventromedian supplements, tail
   curved ventrad and gradually narrowing to a truncate extremity, and
   caudal glands grouped and with terminal spinneret. Mononchus truncatus,
   Clarkus papillatus, C. sheri, Prionchulus muscorum, P. punctatus,
   Coomansus parvus and Iotonchus parabasidontus are recorded for the first
   time from Japan. Additional morphometric data are also provided for
   Actus salvadoricus, Mylonchulus brachyurus, M. sigmaturus, M. oceanicus,
   Iotonchus arcuatus and Miconchus japonicus. And one specimen of an
   unknown species of Miconchus has also been described.
C1 Ahmad, W.; Section of Nematology, Department of Zoology, Aligarh Muslim
   University, Aligarh - 202 002, India, India.
EM ahmadwasim57@yahoo.co.in
SC Zoology
SN 1139-5192

   Eurasia; Asia

PT J
AN ZOOR14706042551
DT Article
TI Paleontology, paleobathymetry, paleoecology, paleogeography and
   stratigraphy distribution of the Rotaliina (benthic foraminifera) from
   the Middle-Late Eocene Mazyad Member of the Dammam Formation in Jabal
   Hafit, Al Ain area, United Arab Emirates, northern Oman Mountains.
AU Anan, Haidar Salim (profanan@gmail.com) 
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 29
IS 1
PS 157-184
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The present study is a part of the comprehensive works concerned with
   the complete record of the small benthic foraminiferal content in the
   Middle-Late Eocene sedimentary sequence in Jabal Hafit (Mazyad Member of
   the Dammam Formation), Al Ain area, United Arab Emirates. The initial
   phase of this study was done in the assemblage of suborders Textulariina
   and Lagenina by the present author (2005 and 2009, respectively). This
   paper is the third part of the same sequence, which concerned with
   taxonomy, paleobathymetry, paleoecology, paleogeography and
   stratigraphic distribution on the suborder Rotaliina assemblage which
   includes 66 species (belonging a42 genera) and two out of them are
   described and illustrated as new: Turrilina hassani and Elphidium
   cherifi.This wide geographic distribution of the recorded Rotaliid
   assemblage emphasizes the interpretations of different authors about the
   extended realms of Indo-Pacific with Atlantic via Tethys during the
   Middle-Late Eocene times.
C1 Anan, Haidar Salim; Department of Geology, Faculty of Science, Al Azhar
   University-Gaza, Gaza, P.O. Box 1277, Palestine, Israel, Israel.
EM profanan@gmail.com

   Middle-Late Eocene / ].

DT Article
TI Upper Cretaceous echinoids from the Galala Plateaux, north eastern
   Desert, Egypt.
AU El Qot, Gamal M. (g_elqot@hotmail.com) 
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 29
IS 1
PS 261-291
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Thirty echinoid species (15 regular and 15 irregular), belonging to 20
   genera, are described from the Upper Cretaceous successions exposed at
   the Abu Darag (Northern Galala), Saint Paul, and Wadi El Dakhl sections
   (Southern Galala). Two new species are established: Heterosalenia
   dakhlensis and Phymosoma kassabi. Both are from the Coniacian of Wadi El
   Dakhl. The rank of the subspecies Mecaster heberti (COQUAND) turonensis
   (FOURTAU) is raised to the species level. The apical disc of the genus
   Pedinopsis COTTEAU, 1863 is illustrated for the first time.
C1 El Qot, Gamal M.; Geology Department, Faculty of Science, Benha
   University, Benha, Egypt, Egypt.
EM g_elqot@hotmail.com

   Cretaceous / ].

   [Cretaceous /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14706046388
DT Article
TI Speciation and dispersal in a low diversity taxon: the slender geckos
   Hemiphyllodactylus (Reptilia, Gekkonidae).
AU Zug, George R. (zugg@si.edu) 
SO Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology
VL 631
PS i-viii, 1-67
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hemiphyllodactylus is a genus of small geckos occurring widely, although
   uncommonly seen, throughout the Indo-Pacific islands and South Asia.
   These geckos consist of both bisexual and unisexual species. The
   unisexual species, Hemiphyllodactylus typus, the most widespread of
   these geckos, apparently attained its Polynesian to Mascarene
   distribution (invasion) through accidental human transport. The bisexual
   species have much smaller distributions, geographically restricted to
   island groups or limited continental areas. Until the early 1990s, most
   bisexual populations were considered subspecies of H. typus. In the last
   two decades, herpetologists have regularly used species epithets
   proposed for the region under their investigation. This resurrection of
   species names has occurred largely without explanation or taxonomic
   study. This study examines the morphology of Hemiphyllodactylus
   throughout its known range, using 13 regional samples, first examining
   the differentiation of unisexual and bisexual populations and
   individuals, then the possibility of regional differentiation among the
   different bisexual populations. Variation and consistency in morphology
   in and among the regional sample identify the existence of a
   wide-ranging unisexual species, H. typus, and at least eight
   geographically restricted bisexual species. Available museum specimens
   for some regions are adequate to characterize eight bisexual species, H.
   aurantiacus, H. ganoklonis n. sp., H. harterti, H. insularis, H.
   larutensis, H. margarethae, H. titiwangsaensis n. sp., and H.
   yunnanensis. Potentially unique bisexual populations occur in Hong Kong,
   southern Indochina, Borneo, and Sri Lanka, but samples are too small to
   adequately characterize these populations. The origins and evolution of
   the species are examined, and the study concludes with a taxonomy for
   the identified species.
C1 Zug, George R.; Department of Vertebrate Zoology, National Museum of
   Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, PO Box 37012, Washington, DC
   20013-7012, USA, USA.
EM zugg@si.edu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0081-0282
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Taxonomy; Key;
   Animals and man; Evolution; Variation; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands
DE Hemiphyllodactylus [Speciation /  / systematics] [Morphological
   variation /  / ] [Dispersal /  / ] [Land zones / Indo-Pacific realm /
   distribution]. 
   Hemiphyllodactylus ganoklonis [Palau /  / New species]. 
   Hemiphyllodactylus titiwangsaensis [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Hemiphyllodactylus types [Vernacular names / Proposed English name / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Sauria, Gekkonidae

   P. 51]. 
   Hemiphyllodactylus - Bleeker 1860 (Gekkonidae): [Key to species, P. 52].

   designated, P. 37].

DT Article
TI [Devonian brachiopods of the Cantabrian Cordillera (north Spain). 8)
   Maisotia n. gen. (Terebratulida) of the Late Emsian (Lower Devonian).]
FT Braquiopodos Devonicos de la Cordillera Cantabrica (N de Espana). 8)
   Maisotia n. gen. (Terebratulido) del Emsiense terminal (Devonico
   Inferior).
AU Garcia-Alcalde, J.L. (jalcalde@geol.uniovi.es) 
SO Trabajos de Geologia
VL 30
PS 386-394
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Terebratulida has been the last order of articulate brachiopods to
   appear in the stratigraphical record, near the base of Devonian or a bit
   earlier. They reached the Recent with a diversity close to that of
   Devonian, ca. 7% of the known genera in the Period. A new genus of the
   order, Maisotia n.gen. is described herein. This genus is characterized
   both by the cordiform outline, with an emarginate anterior commissure,
   and by the more or less truncate margins, and internally by a
   cryptonelliform loop. The new genus is composed by upper Emsian forms,
   as the type-species, M. drotae n.sp. and M. truyolsi (Garcia-Alcalde,
   1999), of the Cantabrian Mountains (North of Spain), and with some
   doubts by M. ? juno (Barrois, 1882) of the Armorican Massif (France).
   The morphologic variation along the ontogeny of the type-species is
   analyzed.
C1 Garcia-Alcalde, J.L.; Area de Paleontologia, Departamento de Geologia,
   Universidad de Oviedo, c/Jesus Arias de Velasco s/n, 33005 Oviedo,
   Spain, Spain.
EM jalcalde@geol.uniovi.es
SC Zoology
SN 0474-9588; 1988-5172
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Maisotia [Devonian /  / New genus]. 
   Maisotia drotae [Spain /  / new species] [Devonian /  / ]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda
OR Centronella? juno - Barrois 1889 (Brachiopoda): [Referred to, New genus
   Maisotia, p. 388; Fossil]. 
   Cryptonella truyolsi - Garcia-Alcalde 1999 (Brachiopoda): [Referred to,
   New genus Maisotia, p. 388; Fossil]. 
   Maisotia (Brachiopoda): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Cryptonellinae, Type
   species Maisotia drotae, p. 387, Devonian; Fossil]. 
   Maisotia drotae (Brachiopoda): [Sp nov, Spain, Devonian, P. 389;
   Fossil]. 
   Maisotia truyolsi - (Garcia-Alcalde 1999) (Brachiopoda): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Cryptonella, p. 388; Fossil]. 
   Maisotia? juno - (Barrois 1889) (Brachiopoda): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Centronella, p. 388; Fossil].

DT Article
TI [Devonian brachiopods of the Cantabrian Cordillera (N de Espana). 9)
   Pentamerelloides n. gen. (Pentameridina Clorindoidea) of the Middle
   Givetian.]
FT Braquiopodos Devonicos de la Cordillera Cantabrica (N de Espana). 9)
   Pentamerelloides n. gen. (Pentameridina Clorindoidea) del Givetiense
   medio.
AU Garcia-Alcalde, J.L. (jalcalde@geol.uniovi.es) 
SO Trabajos de Geologia
VL 30
PS 421-431
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of the numerous Pentamerella Hall, 1867 species (near 50
   different forms) indicates two different genera are at least embraced
   therein, Pentamerella s.str., with Euroamerican, Lower to Middle
   Devonian, relatively great, pentameroid species, and Pentamerelloides
   n.gen. The new taxon is composed by Spirifer Davidsoni Schnur, 1853 as
   the type-species and other Middle Devonian related species with small
   spiriferoid shell. Pentamerelloides n.gen. originated also in the
   paleocontinent Euroamerica, but migrated later along the Givetian to
   Gondwana (Iberian Peninsula and South China), and Siberia-Kazakhstania
   (Salair).
C1 Garcia-Alcalde, J.L.; Area de Paleontologia, Departamento de Geologia,
   Universidad de Oviedo, c/Jesus Arias de Velasco s/n, 33005 Oviedo,
   Spain, Spain.
EM jalcalde@geol.uniovi.es

DT Article
TI [Devonian brachiopods of the Cantrabrian Cordillera (north Spain). 10)
   Argovejia n. gen. (Retzioidea) of the Upper Emsian (Lower Devonian).]
FT Braquiopodos Devonicos de la Cordillera Cantabrica (N de Espana). 10)
   Argovejia n. gen. (Retzioidea) del Emsiense superior (Devonico
   Inferior).
AU Garcia-Alcalde, J.L. (jalcalde@geol.uniovi.es) 
SO Trabajos de Geologia
VL 30
PS 452-459
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Retziidine brachiopods are a minor fraction of the Cantabrian Mountains
   (North Spain) Devonian faunas. Two rare, unpublished forms, close to
   Rhynchospirina are known from the Palentian Domain Pragian and from the
   Astur-Leonian lower Emsian, respectively. The group achieved a maximum
   of diversity along the Astur-Leonian upper Emsian. Two species of
   Retzia, R. adrieni and R. cf. prominula, Cooperispira subferita, and a
   possible unpublished Plectospira species occur therein. Retziidinids are
   not known along the Cantabrian Middle and Upper Devonian and reappear in
   the Pensylvanian with several Hustedia forms. A new taxon of the Family
   Retziidae, Argovejia n.gen. is proposed herein. The new genus is
   composed by its type-species, A. talenti n.sp. from the uppermost Emsian
   of Asturias and Leon, and perhaps by Retzia haidingeri var. armoricana
   and Retzia haidingeri var. dichotoma from the upper Emsian of the
   Armorican Massif (France).
C1 Garcia-Alcalde, J.L.; Area de Paleontologia, Departamento de Geologia,
   Universidad de Oviedo, c/Jesus Arias de Velasco s/n, 33005 Oviedo,
   Spain, Spain.
EM jalcalde@geol.uniovi.es

SN 0474-9588; 1988-5172

   Argovejia talenti [Spain /  / new species] [Devonian /  / ].

   Argovejia talenti, p. 453, Devonian; Fossil]. 
   Argovejia haidingeri var. armoricana - (Barrois 1889) (Brachiopoda):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Retzia, p. 455; Fossil]. 
   Argovejia haidingeri var. dichotoma - (Barrois 1889) (Brachiopoda):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Retzia, p. 455; Fossil].

TI Review of the genus Batakomacrus Kolarov, 1986 (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae, Orthocentrinae) with description of new species.
AU Humala, A.E. (humala@krc.karelia.ru) 
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 81
IS 2
PS 29-38
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Batakomacrus Kolarov is reviewed and five new species are
   described: B. karelicus sp. n., B. sylvicola sp. n. and B. subarcticus
   sp. n. from Karelia, B. mongolicus sp. n. from Mongolia and B. hidalgo
   sp. n. from Mexico. Key to all species of Batakomacrus is provided. The
   new data on distribution of B. caudatus (Holmgren) is given.

DT Article
TI HYMENOLEPIDOID CESTODES (CYCLOPHYLLIDAE, HYMENOLEPIDOIDAE) OF PRATINCOLE
   (GLAREOLA PRATINCOLA) FROM THE SOUTH OF UKRAINE.
AU Kornyushin, V.V.
   Greben, O.B.
SO Vestnik Zoologii
VL 44
IS 6
PS 495-507
PD Noyabr-Dekabr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four hymenolepidoid cestode species Glareolepis porale (Meggitt, 1927)
   Spassky, 1967; Wardium (s. l.). tauricum Kornyushin et Greben, sp. n.;
   Wardium (s. l.) sp. n.; and Echinocotyloides longirostris (Rudolphi,
   1819) Kornyushin, 1983 from pratincole from the Southern Ukraine are
   discribed. The morphology of G. porale is described in details. An
   interesting new observation is that testes are lacking in female
   proglottides of G. porale; the structures described in literature as
   testes in hermaphroditic proglottides are, in fact, ovarian lobes. The
   new cestode species Wardium (s. I.) tauricum sp. n. is described. It is
   characterised by aploparaksoid hooks, 13-15 [mu]m long, and conical
   armed cirrus, 20-22 [mu]m long. Another cestode species, Wardium (s. l.)
   sp., is identified to the generic level only. It differs from all the
   species of the genus in the. size and armament of the cirrus; however,
   no scolex was present in the material studied.
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0084-5604
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy;
   Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Echinocotyloides longirostris; Glareolepis porale [Avian hosts /
   Glareola pratincola / Systematics] [Ukraine / Crimea / ]. 
   Glareola pratincola [Cestode parasites / Echinocotyloides longirostris /
   Parasite redescription] [ / Glareolepis porale / ] [ / Wardium (Wardium)
   tauricum / New parasite species] [ / Wardium / ] [Ukraine /  / New
   platyhelminth parasite species] [ / Crimea / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Wardium [Avian hosts / Glareola pratincola / ] [Ukraine / Crimea / ]. 
   Wardium (Wardium) tauricum [Avian hosts / Glareola pratincola / New
   parasite species] [Ukraine /  / New species from avian host]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Charadriiformes, Glareolidae,
   Platyhelminthes, Cestoda
OR Glareola pratincola (Glareolidae): [Host]. 
   Echinocotyloides longirostris - (Rudolphi 1819) (Cestoda):
   [Redescription, P. 506; Parasite]. 
   Glareolepis - Spassky 1967 (Cestoda): [Emended diagnosis, P. 500;
   Removal from synonymy, With Wardium, p. 500]. 
   Glareolepis porale - Meggitt 1927 (Cestoda): [Redescription, P. 496;
   Parasite]. 
   Wardium (Cestoda): [Removal from synonymy, Glareolepis Spassky 1967, p.
   500; Parasite]. 
   Wardium (Wardium) tauricum (Cestoda): [Sp nov, Ukraine, Parasite of
   Glareola pratincola (Aves), p. 500; Parasite].

DT Article
TI On the occurrence of Polynema Haliday (Dorypolynema Hayat and Anis) and
   Palaeoneura Waterhouse (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) in the New World, with
   description of two new species.
AU Triapitsyn, Serguei V.
   Aquino, Daniel A.
SO Acta Zoologica Lilloana
VL 54
IS 1-2
PS 61-77
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the subgenus Dorypolynema Hayat and Anis of the
   fairyfly genus Polynema Haliday (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae), is described
   from Argentina, Brazil, Costa Rica, Ecuador, and Peru. The genus
   Palaeoneura Waterhouse is recorded from the Nearctic region. Palaeoneura
   mymaripennis (Dozier) comb. n. from Polynema, previously known only from
   the USA, is also recorded from the Neotropical region (Guatemala,
   Honduras, and Panama). Its female is redescribed and the male is
   described. A new species of Palaeoneura is described from Guatemala and
   USA (Florida). Chaetomymar tayalum Taguchi from Taiwan (China) is
   transferred to Palaeoneura as P. tayalum (Taguchi) comb. n.; P. clotho
   (Debauche) comb. n. and P. oreades (Debauche) comb. n. (both from
   Democratic Republic of the Congo) are transferred to Palaeoneura from
   Polynema.
C1 Triapitsyn, Serguei V.; Entomology Research Museum, Department of
   Entomology, University of California, Riverside, California 92521, USA,
   USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0065-1729
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Nearctic
   region; Neotropical region; Africa; North America; USA; Central America;
   South America
DE Palaeoneura [Land zones / New World / Key to species] [Nearctic region /
    / New record] [Madagascar /  / ]. 
   Palaeoneura durwest [Florida /  / New species] [Guatemala /  / ]. 
   Polynema (Dorypolynema) [Madagascar /  / New record]. 
   Polynema (Dorypolynema) gaucho [Costa Rica /  / New species] [Argentina
   /  / ] [Brazil /  / ] [Ecuador /  / ] [Peru /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Proctotrupoidea, Mymaridae
OR Chaetomymar tayalum - Taguchi 1975 (Mymaridae): [Referred to,

DT Article
TI Pukuakanga salignea, a new genus and species of Dictyopharidae
   (Hemiptera: Auchenorrhyncha: Fulgoromorpha) from Southeastern Brazil.
FT Pukuakanga salignea, genero novo e especie nova de Dictyopharidae
   (Hemiptera: Auchenorrhyncha: Fulgoromorpha) do sudeste do Brasil.
AU Baptista, Marcelo da Silva (baptistams@gmail.com) 
   Serrao, Jose Eduardo
   Da-Silva, Elidiomar Ribeiro
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 10
IS 4
PS 95-100
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/fullpaper?bn01510042010+pt
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Pukuakanga gen. nov., a new genus of Dictyopharidae, is established
   based on adult specimens of a new species, Pukuakanga salignea sp.nov.,
   from different municipalities of Minas Gerais State, Brazil. The genus
   can be determined by a characters combination like: head length 4.8x
   width of the base; apex of head projection showing the union of marginal
   carinae of the front and vertex laterally to projection; carina tegulae
   absence; anteromedian margin of pronotum straight, three rows of cells
   on membrane of fore wing; aedeagus with the conjunctiva bifurcated
   forming two pairs of tubes, and the thorn of the penis showing a lateral
   branch.
C1 Baptista, Marcelo da Silva; Laboratorio de Insetos Aquaticos,
   Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Biociencias, Universidade Federal
   do Estado do Rio de Janeiro [long dash] UNIRIO, CEP 22290-240, Rio de
   Janeiro, RJ, Brazil, Brazil.
EM baptistams@gmail.com

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041301
DT Article
TI Insect galls of the Reserva Biologica Estadual da Praia do Sul (Ilha
   Grande, Angra dos Reis, RJ).
FT Galhas de insetos da Reserva Biologica Estadual da Praia do Sul (Ilha
   Grande, Angra dos Reis, RJ).
AU Maia, Valeria Cid (maiavcid@acd.ufrj.br) 
   de Oliveira, Jussara Costa
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 10
IS 4
PS 227-238
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/download?inventory+bn04110042
   010+pt
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 5
AB Thirty-six morphotypes of insect galls were recorded for the first time
   in the Reserva Biologica Estadual da Praia do Sul (Ilha Grande, Angra
   dos Reis, RJ), being the majority of them comprised of leaf galls (64%).
   Stem and bud galls were also found (25 and 14%, respectively). Myrtaceae
   were the plant family with the greatest richness of insect galls.
   Mikania sp. (Asteraceae) and Guapira opposita (Nyctaginaceae) were the
   super host plant species. The most important galling group was the
   Cecidomyiidae (Diptera), responsible for 75% of the gall morphotypes.
   Hemipteran and Lepidopteran galls were also recorded (11 and 2.8%,
   respectively).
C1 Maia, Valeria Cid; Museu Nacional, Quinta da Boa Vista, Sao Cristovao,
   CEP 20940-040, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil, Brazil.
EM maiavcid@acd.ufrj.br

OI Maia, Valeria/0000-0001-9396-5618

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041302
DT Article
TI Anting behavior by the White-bearded Manakin (Manacus manacus,
   Pipridae): an example of functional interaction in a frugivorous lekking
   bird.
AU Cestari, Cesar (cesar_cestari@yahoo.com.br) 
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 10
IS 4
PS 339-342
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/fullpaper?bn02110042010+en
LA English
U1 1
U2 20
AB Behavioral studies of birds have reported several functions for active
   anting. Maintenance of plumage and prevention from ectoparasites are
   some examples. In this context, anting by males may be of particular
   importance in a classical lek mating system, where male-male competition
   is common and individuals with higher fitness may be more successful at
   attracting of females. In the present note, I describe the anting
   behavior of White-bearded Manakin (Manacus manacus) and I relate it to
   lek breeding and feeding (frugivory) habits of the species. Males used
   up to seven Solenopsis sp. ants. They rubbed each small ant from 4 to 31
   times on undertail feathers until the ants were degraded; ants were not
   eaten. Males then searched for a new ant in the court. Seeds discarded
   by males on their individual display courts attract herbivorous ants
   that are used for anting as a way to maintain feathers and fitness. I
   hypothesize that anting in White-bearded Manakin may increase the
   probability of males to attract females to their display courts.
C1 Cestari, Cesar; Departamento de Zoologia, Programa de Pos-graduacao em
   Zoologia, Universidade Estadual Paulista "Julio de Mesquita Filho" [long
   dash] UNESP, Campus de Rio Claro, CEP 13506-900, Rio Claro, SP, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM cesar_cestari@yahoo.com.br
RI Cestari, Cesar/G-2918-2011
OI Cestari, Cesar/0000-0002-6237-7618
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Behavioral
   Sciences; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1806-129X; 1676-0611
BD Nutrition; Diet; Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Behaviour;
   Comfort behaviour; Ecology; Competition; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Manacus manacus [Food plants /  / Frugivory; new record] [Courtship /
   Lekking / ] [Anting /  / ] [Intraspecific competition / Male-male
   competition / ] [Brazil / Sao Paulo, Itanhaem & Jureia Itatins
   Ecological Station / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Pipridae
OR Manacus manacus (Pipridae): [New record]. 
DI 10.1590/S1676-06032010000400038

OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041285
DT Article
TI Mycale alagoana sp. nov. and two new formal records of Porifera
   (Demospongiae, Poecilosclerida) from the shallow-water reefs of Alagoas
   (Brazil).
FT Mycale alagoana sp. nov. e dois novos registros formais de Porifera
   (Demospongiae, Poecilosclerida) dos recifes rasos de Alagoas, Brasil.
AU Cedro, Victor Ribeiro (vrcedro@gmail.com) 
   Hajdu, Eduardo
   Correia, Monica Dorigo
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 10
IS 4
PS Unpaginated
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v10n4/pt/abstract?article+bn0241101201
   1
NT Unpaginated.
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Porifera occurring at Alagoas State reefs (north-eastern Brazil) are
   still little-known, with few species listed and even fewer formally
   described. From a total of 48 species recorded from the state, only
   eight belong to the Poecilosclerida, including those (re)described in
   this study. Here we describe a new species, Mycale (Mycale ) alagoana
   sp.nov., and redescribe two species: Lissodendoryx (Lissodendoryx )
   isodictyalis (Carter, 1882) and Mycale (Naviculina ) diversisigmata Van
   Soest, 1984, both first formal redescriptions from the Southwestern
   Atlantic. Additionally, Mycale (Aegogropila ) escarlatei Hajdu et al.,
   1995 is here reported from Alagoas for the first time, in discussing the
   difficulties inherent to recognition in the field of small crustose
   Mycalids with neatly reticulated surfaces.
C1 Cedro, Victor Ribeiro; Universidade Federal de Alagoas, Programa de
   Pos-graduacao em Diversidade Biologica e Conservacao nos Tropicos, Praca
   Afranio Jorge, s/n, CEP 57.010-020, Maceio, AL, Brazil, Brazil.
EM vrcedro@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1806-129X; 1676-0611
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean

   diversisigmata [South Atlantic / West / New record]. 
   Mycale (Aegogropila) escarlatei [South Atlantic / Brazil, Alagoas / New
   record]. 
   Mycale (Mycale) alagoana [South Atlantic / Brazil / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Lissodendoryx (Lissodendoryx) isodictyalis - (Carter 1882)
   (Demospongiae): [Redescription; New record].

   [Redescription; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14705042265
DT Article
TI Representatives of Nematodes of the Genus Bursaphelenchus (Aphelenchida,
   Parasitophelenchidae) in Georgia.
AU Mikaia, Nona
   Devdariani, Tsiala
   Gninenko, Yuri
SO Bulletin of the Georgian National Academy of Sciences
VL 4
IS 1
PS 146-151
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Species associated with insects are united in the genus Bursaphelenchus.
   There are pests of plants among them: Bursaphelenchus cocophilus damages
   coco palm, and Bursaphelenchus xylophilus conifer species, hence the
   great attention paid to the given genus of nematodes. In the process of
   study of nematodes associated with insects a great quantity of species
   of the genus Bursaphelenchus have been recorded in Georgia. In the list
   of nematodes of the order Aphelenchida 23 species are noted for Georgia.
   Of them 10 are described as new to science. However, the Bursaphelenchus
   scalari Kakulia, 1989, described by Kakulia is missing in the list. A
   certain part, due to the absence of description in print, appeared to be
   nomina nuda or to be unknown to the authors. In the present paper
   attempts are made to fill the gap.
C1 Mikaia, Nona; L. Kanchaveli Institute of Plant Protection, Tbilisi,
   Georgia-Asia, Georgia-Asia.

   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts;
   Transmission; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI Description of Upper Visean rugose corals from Penarroya-Pueblonuevo
   (Cordova) and El Casar (Badajoz).
FT Descripcion de los corales rugosos del Viseense superior de
   Penarroya-Pueblonuevo (Cordoba) y El Casar (Badajoz).
AU Rodriguez, Sergio (sergrodr@geo.ucm.es) 
   Said, Ismail
SO Coloquios de Paleontologia
VL 59
PS 7-27
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Upper Visean rugose corals from Penarroya-Pueblonuevo and El Casar
   (San Antonio-La Juliana Unit, Cordova and Badajoz) are described. Ten
   species belonging to eight genera have been identified. Axophyllid
   corals are dominant in the assemblage and fasciculate corals are also
   common. On the other hand, no massive rugosans have been collected.
   Occurrence of the genus Amygdalophalloides is recorded for the first
   time older than Serpukhovian with the description of the new species A.
   anticuum. Thus, the record of the family Geyerophyllidae is extended
   from Visean to Permian.
C1 Rodriguez, Sergio; Departamento y UEI de Paleontologia, Facultad de
   Ciencias Geologicas e Instituto de Geologia Economica, UCMCSIC, C/ Jose
   Antonio Novais 2, 28040 Madrid, Spain, Spain.
EM sergrodr@geo.ucm.es

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   record] [Carboniferous / Upper Visean / ].

   ]. 
   Gangamophyllum [Spain / South / new record] [Carboniferous / Upper

PT J
AN ZOOR14705037616
DT Article
TI Umkulunkula gen. nov. - a new genus of Pyralinae (Insecta: Lepidoptera,
   Pyraloidea) from southern Africa.
AU Mey, Wolfram (Wolfram.mey@museum.hu-berlin.de) 
SO Entomologica Romanica
VL 15
PS 5-10
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The new genus Umkulunkula gen. nov. is established here for an
   undescribed pyraline species. It has a wide distribution in southern
   Africa and is named U. kalahariensis sp. nov. The detailed description
   of the species is based on male and female adults and include external
   and genital features. The new genus is characterised by four presumed
   apomorphies: discal spot in forewings with semi-erect scales, male
   genitalia with juxta and separate transtilla forming a forked appendage,
   abdominal segment VIII of females with separate sternite and tergite,
   mid-tibia of both sexes enlarged by long piliform scales. The
   sistergroup is currently unknown. Closely related genera are Pyralis and
   Pyralosis by sharing the same wing form, venation and head morphology.
C1 Mey, Wolfram; Museum fuer Naturkunde, Leibniz Institute at Humboldt
   Universitaet, Invalidenstr. 43, D-10115 Berlin, Germany, Germany.
EM Wolfram.mey@museum.hu-berlin.de
SC Zoology
SN 1224-2594
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Umkulunkula kalahariensis [Botswana /  / New species] [Namibia /  / ]
   [South Africa /  / ] [Zimbabwe /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Pyraloidea, Pyralidae
OR Umkulunkula (Pyralidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Pyralinae, Type species
   Umkulunkula kalahariensis, p. 5]. 
   Umkulunkula kalahariensis (Pyralidae): [Sp nov, South Africa, P. 6]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705037616

DT Article
TI Current state of Ixodidae-research in Mongolia.
AU Kiefer, D. (daniel.kiefer@gmx.net) 
   Pfister, K.
   Tserennorov, D.
   Bolormaa, G.
   Otgonbaatar, D.
   Samjaa, R.
   Burmeister, E.G.
   Kiefer, M.S.
SO Erforschung Biologischer Ressourcen der Mongolei
VL 11
PS 405-418
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Our research presents the Ixodidae-fauna in Mongolia. The current
   taxonomic state in Mongolia shows 19 Ixodidae taxa extracted in 308
   locations from 115 bird and mammal species. In 1980, the species Ixodes
   persulcatus SCHULZE, 1930 and Ixodes berlesei Birula, 1895 were detected
   in Inget Tolgoi and Ixodes laguri OLENEV, 1929 on Meriones unguiculatus
   10 km southeast of Ulaanbaatar for the first time. In 2000 the species
   Haemaphysalis concinna Koch, 1844 was detected in the Selenge-river area
   and Argas (Argas) vulgaris FILIPPOVA, 1961 was detected in the Gobi
   area. From the collection of M. and A. STUBBE 1 N (Nymphae) Ixodes
   persulcatus was detected on Microtus sp. at the Minz-gol (river in
   Khentey) on 25.07.2002.
C1 Kiefer, D.; Institute for Tropical Veterinary Medicine,
   Ludwig-Maximilians-University Munich, Germany, Germany.
EM daniel.kiefer@gmx.net
SC Zoology; Parasitology
BD Documentation; Publications; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Aves; Mammalia [Checklists /  / ] [Arachnid parasites / Ixodidae / ]
   [Mongolia /  / ]. 
   Ixodidae [Checklists /  / ] [Avian hosts /  / ] [Mammalian hosts /  / ]
   [Mongolia /  / distribution]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Birds; Chelicerates; Chordates; Invertebrates;
   Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Ixodidae (Acari): [Parasite]. 
   Aves (Vertebrata): [Host]. 
   Mammalia (Vertebrata): [Host].

DT Article
TI New data on the fauna and taxonomy of Corynoneura Winnertz (Diptera,
   Chironomidae, Orthocladiinae) for the Russian Far East and bordering
   territories.
AU Makarchenko, E.A. (makarchenko@biosoil.ru) 
   Makarchenko, M.A.
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 3
PS 353-370
PD Sentyabr 2010
PY 2010
NT Separate unpaginated plate.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Six a new chironomid species of Corynoneura, C. aurora sp.n. from
   Lazovsky Nature Reserve of Primorye, C. collaris sp.n. from Jewish
   Autonomous Region and Kamchatka, C. kadalinka sp.n. from Chita Region.,
   C. schleei sp.n. from Bolshekhehtsyrsky Nature Reserve of Khabarovsk
   Territory, C. sundukovi sp.n. from Lazovsky District of Primorye
   Territory and C. tertia sp.n. from Kedrovaya Pad' Nature Reserve of
   Primorye Territory, are described and illustrated. Four rare species, C.
   carriana Edwards from Baikal Lake, C. fittkaui Schlee from Primorye, C.
   kibunelata Sasa from South Primorye and C. tokarapequea Sasa et Suzuki
   from Zeya River (Amur River basin), are redescribed, the latter two
   species for the first time outside of Japan. A key to the male imagines
   and pupae of the Far Eastern and East Siberian species is provided.

   other known species of Parakiefferiella Thienemann from the Russian Far
   East are described by some stages of metamorphosis and/or commented on:
   P. bathophila (Kieff.), P. bilobata Tuisk., P. coronata (Edw.), P. rarer
   Makar. et Makar., P. scandica Br., P. smolandica (Br.), P. vshivkovae
   Makar. et Makar. and Parakiefferiella sp. 1. Larva of P. smolandica is
   described for the first time. Key to the males imagines and pupae of the
   Far Eastern species is presented.

TI A revision of the Anthaxia (Haplanthaxia) zanzibarica species-group
   (Coleoptera: Buprestidae: Buprestinae: Anthaxiini).
AU Bily, Svatopluk (svatopluk_bily@nm.cz) 
SO Folia Heyrovskyana
VL 18
IS 1-3
PS 1-23
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A taxonomic revision of the Anthaxia (Haplanthaxia) zanzibarica
   Kerremans, 1898 species-group with the description of five new species:
   Anthaxia (H.) acutipennis sp. nov. (Tanzania), A. (H.) beninensis sp.
   nov. (Benin), A. (H.) cadifortnis sp. nov. (Ethiopia. Kenya, Tanzania),
   A. (H.) glabricollis sp. nov. (Kenya) and A. (H.) putpureifis ns sp.
   nov. (Tanzania, Zambia). Two new synonyms are proposed: Anthaxia (H.)
   ikuthana Obenberger, 1928 = A. (H.) chrulaensis Thdry, 1941, syn. nov.
   and A. (H.) zanzibarica Kerremans, 1898 = A. (H.) vassei Kerremans,
   1913, syn. nov. and a lectotype is designated for A. (H) ikuthana
   Obenberger, 1928. All species are illustrated and a key for
   identification of all species is provided.

DT Article
TI Sphallomorpha bilyi sp. nov. from Australia (Carabidae:
   Pseudomorphinae).
AU Baehr, Martin (martin.baehr@zsm.mwn.de) 
SO Folia Heyrovskyana
VL 18
IS 1-3
PS 59-66
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the subfamily Pseudomorphinae (Carabidae) from the
   Northern Territory of Australia is described: Sphallomorpha bilyi sp.
   nov. According to characters of external and genitalic morphology it
   belongs to the S. grandis (Laporte de Castelnau, 1867) species-group,
   but is the smallest member of this group so far recorded. The new
   species is introduced in the key to the species of the genus.
C1 Baehr, Martin; Zoologische Staatssammlung, Muenchhausenstr. 21, D-81247
   Muenchen, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Notes on the Toxidium group (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Scaphidiinae).
AU Loebl, Ivan (ivan.lobl@bluewin.ch) 
   Leschen, Richard A.B.
SO Folia Heyrovskyana
VL 18
IS 1-3
PS 71-93
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We clarify taxonomic issues in the Toxidium LeConte, 1860 group sencu
   LESCHEN & LOEBL (2005) by examining type material and describing new
   species of the genera Scaphicoma Motschulsky, 1863 and Toxidium. The
   following species are described: Scaphicoma monteithi sp. nov. from
   Australia (Queensland), S. yapo sp. nov. from the Ivory Coast, Toxidium
   janaki sp. nov. and T. rougemonti sp. nov. from Madagascar, and T.
   storeri sp. nov. from Queensland. Toxidium collarti Pic, 1930 syn. nov.,
   is placed in synonymy with Scaphicoma antennalis (Achard, 1922) and T.
   reitteri Oberthur, 1884 syn. nov., is placed in synonymy with
   Scaphobaeocera oberthueri (Reitter, 1881). A lectotype of T. collard is
   designated. Following species are transferred from Toxidium:
   Baeoccridium piceonotatum (Pic, 1954) comb. nov., Scaphicoma rufa (Pic,
   1923) comb. nov., Scaphicoma incertum (Pic, 1954) comb. nov.,
   Scaphohaeocera oberthueri (Reitter, 1881) comb. nov., S. Integra
   (Reitter, 1908) comb. nov., S. brevipennis (Pic, 1947) comb. nov.,
   Scaphoxium praslinense (Scott, 1922) comb. nov. and S. seychellense
   (Scott, 1922) comb. nov.
C1 Loebl, Ivan; Museum d'Histoire Naturelle, Route de Malagnou 1, CH-1208,
   Geneve, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM ivan.lobl@bluewin.ch
SC Zoology
SN 1210-4108
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Australasian region; Africa; Australasia; Australia

   Scaphisoma incertum - (Pic 1954) (Staphylinidae): [Redescription, P. 90;

   Scaphobaeocera brevipennis - (Pic 1947) (Staphylinidae): [Redescription,

TI New or rare Madagascan tiger beetles - 15 Pogonostoma (Microstenocera)
   zombitsynense sp. nov., a new species from southwestern Madagascar
   (Coleoptera: Cicindelidae).
AU Moravec, Jiri (jirmor@quick.cz) 
   Vybiral, Jan
SO Folia Heyrovskyana
VL 18
IS 1-3
PS 95-102
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the Madagascar endemic genus Pogonostoma Klug 1835, P.
   (Microstenocera) zombitsynense sp. nov., belonging to the P. (M.)
   pusilium (Laporte de Castelnau & Gory, 1835) species group, is described
   from the Zombitse-Vohibasia National Park in southwestern Madagascar and
   compared with related taxa. A supplemental key to species of the P (M.)
   pusillum species group is appended.
